description: This show focuses on the second in a three exam series for Microsoft's MCSA Server 2016 and focuses on the networking features and functionality. It covers DNS, DHCP, and IPAM implementations, in addition to remote access solutions, such as VPN and Direct Access. It also covers DFS and BranchCache solutions, high performance network features and functionality, and implementation of software-defined networking (SDN) solutions, such as Hyper-V Network Virtualization (HNV) and Network Controller.

1

[SOUND]

Server 2016 series, I'm your show host,

5
00:00:16.505 --> 00:00:17.428
Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:17.428 --> 00:00:18.907
So we've made it to part 3,

7
00:00:18.907 --> 00:00:22.410
where we're continuing to look
at IP version 4 networks.

8
00:00:22.410 --> 00:00:24.797
Back in studios with us today we have Mr.
Adam Gordon.

9
00:00:24.797 --> 00:00:27.280
Thanks for joining us today, Adam.

10
00:00:27.280 --> 00:00:28.470
>> Great to be here as always.

11
00:00:28.470 --> 00:00:31.970
Continuing our conversations
associated with IPv4.

12
00:00:31.970 --> 00:00:35.320
We've taken a look at many of
the building blocks and pieces,

13
00:00:35.320 --> 00:00:38.630
took a little detour into PowerShell and
the command line.

14
00:00:38.630 --> 00:00:41.840
In the last episode took a look
at PowerShell cmdlets, and

15
00:00:41.840 --> 00:00:43.030
we also took a look at Netsh and

16
00:00:43.030 --> 00:00:45.866
just began to explore some of
the functionality we could find there.

17
00:00:45.866 --> 00:00:49.010
So I just wanted to remind you
with regards to Netsh by the way,

18
00:00:49.010 --> 00:00:50.340
just take a look quickly on my machine.

19
00:00:50.340 --> 00:00:52.140
I forgot to put this up
in the last episode,

20
00:00:52.140 --> 00:00:54.650
but as long as we get it in there
somewhere, I suppose it's good.

21
00:00:54.650 --> 00:00:57.260
You could see with Netsh that there
is a list of all the commands that

22
00:00:57.260 --> 00:01:00.850
are available on the web just like
there is for everything else.

23
00:01:00.850 --> 00:01:04.040
As we scroll down, you will see that
Netsh has been around forever and

24
00:01:04.040 --> 00:01:04.880
a day by the way.

25
00:01:04.880 --> 00:01:07.500
So Netsh is not one of those new things.

26
00:01:07.500 --> 00:01:11.250
Netsh has been around since NT4 and
it's been around forever.

27
00:01:11.250 --> 00:01:13.770
So you can see here that we can go in and

28
00:01:13.770 --> 00:01:16.400
we could see all of the different
commands that are available.

29
00:01:16.400 --> 00:01:21.040
And it's a very, very detailed tool
that lets us manage any and every aspect

30
00:01:21.040 --> 00:01:25.300
of IP configuration interface management
for any interface on the system.

31
00:01:25.300 --> 00:01:27.805
So it would be worth your time
to check it out real quick.

32
00:01:27.805 --> 00:01:31.128
We wanted to continue our
conversation around a little bit of

33
00:01:31.128 --> 00:01:32.830
a different thought process.

34
00:01:32.830 --> 00:01:35.750
I just wanna scroll over
just a little smidge there,

35
00:01:35.750 --> 00:01:37.370
just to show you the edge of this.

36
00:01:37.370 --> 00:01:40.600
And I'm gonna type in the route command.

37
00:01:40.600 --> 00:01:45.130
And when I do that you'll see that
we get just a help file for route.

38
00:01:45.130 --> 00:01:49.080
You can see it tells us the information
about how we can pull up

39
00:01:49.080 --> 00:01:50.750
the route command, what we can use it for.

40
00:01:50.750 --> 00:01:53.340
The route command,
route print specifically,

41
00:01:53.340 --> 00:01:54.760
will let us see the routing table.

42
00:01:54.760 --> 00:01:56.450
I had it up in a prior episode.

43
00:01:56.450 --> 00:02:00.160
Route add will let us manipulate an add,
either static routes in or

44
00:02:00.160 --> 00:02:01.640
specify a certain route.

45
00:02:01.640 --> 00:02:04.020
We can modify the routes that are there.

46
00:02:04.020 --> 00:02:06.370
So the route command again,
been around forever.

47
00:02:06.370 --> 00:02:09.090
And many people just don't even
think about or don't really use it.

48
00:02:09.090 --> 00:02:12.520
They'll go in and they'll specify and
configure IP information,

49
00:02:12.520 --> 00:02:14.200
as we talked about,
from one of the other interfaces.

50
00:02:14.200 --> 00:02:17.400
But we can do this right
from in here if we want to,

51
00:02:17.400 --> 00:02:21.100
and when we do that we do route print.

52
00:02:23.420 --> 00:02:26.920
As we saw, we could see the routing table.

53
00:02:26.920 --> 00:02:29.460
In this case, this is server 16.

54
00:02:29.460 --> 00:02:34.000
And so we can see we have both a routing
table for IPv6 down at the bottom there.

55
00:02:34.000 --> 00:02:38.039
And we have one for IPv4,
just a little further up right here.

56
00:02:39.050 --> 00:02:41.701
And we can see the routing
table is listed for both.

57
00:02:41.701 --> 00:02:43.298
And when we look at a routing table,

58
00:02:43.298 --> 00:02:46.246
we want to understand the different
information that's there.

59
00:02:46.246 --> 00:02:49.110
So I just wanna quickly identify
the five key elements that make up

60
00:02:49.110 --> 00:02:52.200
the table here and just make sure
we're comfortable with what they are.

61
00:02:52.200 --> 00:02:55.620
The network destination,
right here, the netmask,

62
00:02:55.620 --> 00:02:57.640
the gateway, the interface and the metric.

63
00:02:57.640 --> 00:02:59.300
Let's just talk about what those are.

64
00:02:59.300 --> 00:03:02.760
Let's start with the network destination.

65
00:03:02.760 --> 00:03:05.750
This is the destination host where traffic
is going to be transmitted, right?

66
00:03:05.750 --> 00:03:09.630
So in other words, this is what we
are thinking about sending our traffic to.

67
00:03:09.630 --> 00:03:11.580
It's whatever this address is.

68
00:03:11.580 --> 00:03:14.500
When we think about the netmask we're
thinking about the subnet mask.

69
00:03:14.500 --> 00:03:15.870
Just highlight that as we go.

70
00:03:15.870 --> 00:03:18.720
The subnet mask that we will be using,
we've talked about subnet masks.

71
00:03:18.720 --> 00:03:20.635
You would know hopefully
by now what they are.

72
00:03:20.635 --> 00:03:23.930
When we think about the gateway,
the gateway is going to be that

73
00:03:23.930 --> 00:03:28.810
interface that allows us to be able to
get out of our system across our LAN and

74
00:03:28.810 --> 00:03:31.240
then specify connectivity
to another network.

75
00:03:31.240 --> 00:03:33.960
So that's the target we're
gonna send our traffic to,

76
00:03:33.960 --> 00:03:37.140
to route traffic on a IPv4
network in this case.

77
00:03:37.140 --> 00:03:41.650
The interface itself, the IPv4
address that we are using to send and

78
00:03:41.650 --> 00:03:45.470
receive traffic on this particular
machine, whatever this may be for

79
00:03:45.470 --> 00:03:47.120
the route in question.

80
00:03:47.120 --> 00:03:50.890
Notice all this information is
entered as a series of items, right,

81
00:03:50.890 --> 00:03:54.598
going across horizontally as
a row inside the routing table.

82
00:03:54.598 --> 00:03:59.490
Each one of the items we're
defining has a unique identifier or

83
00:03:59.490 --> 00:04:00.610
entry associated with it.

84
00:04:00.610 --> 00:04:03.450
And then the metric is
the relative cost for the route.

85
00:04:04.570 --> 00:04:11.610
Metric is a number that gets assigned that
then is going to translate into a priority

86
00:04:11.610 --> 00:04:17.130
for the route, if you will, the cost
being high or low based on the number.

87
00:04:17.130 --> 00:04:19.930
So the lower the metric number,
the lower the cost.

88
00:04:19.930 --> 00:04:22.074
The higher the metric number,
the higher the cost.

89
00:04:22.074 --> 00:04:26.950
And so a metric of 10 would be lower and
therefore less costly to

90
00:04:26.950 --> 00:04:31.800
use than a metric of 281, or 331, or
whatever numbers you may see there.

91
00:04:31.800 --> 00:04:33.300
They're more expensive, quote, unquote.

92
00:04:33.300 --> 00:04:34.498
Now I talked to people about it.

93
00:04:34.498 --> 00:04:37.170
So it's like, you get out money,
you start, no, we don't do that.

94
00:04:37.170 --> 00:04:38.300
This is not money.

95
00:04:38.300 --> 00:04:43.290
When we say costs, what we mean is that we
are simply specifying the numerical value

96
00:04:43.290 --> 00:04:45.000
that indicates our preference for

97
00:04:45.000 --> 00:04:49.530
the route based on a lower number being
more preferable than a higher number.

98
00:04:49.530 --> 00:04:51.810
But we just,
we tend to refer to it as a cost value.

99
00:04:51.810 --> 00:04:52.954
That's how the metric is often
documented and described.

100
00:04:52.954 --> 00:04:54.539
>> It just has some logic.

101
00:04:54.539 --> 00:04:56.300
It has good logic behind it, though.

102
00:04:56.300 --> 00:05:00.870
If you have a cheeseburger over here for
$10 versus a cheeseburger for $5, and

103
00:05:00.870 --> 00:05:02.480
they both fill you up.

104
00:05:02.480 --> 00:05:05.420
Kinda like it gets you to the same place,
so which route would you wanna choose?

105
00:05:05.420 --> 00:05:09.350
Usually you're looking at the one with
the lower, was that the $5 burger?

106
00:05:09.350 --> 00:05:10.857
The lower metric there, right?

107
00:05:10.857 --> 00:05:11.390
[LAUGH]
>> I am

108
00:05:11.390 --> 00:05:15.332
not inserting myself into your
cheeseburger world, young ladyship!

109
00:05:15.332 --> 00:05:18.392
I'm gonna leave that totally up to
you [LAUGH] to decide whether left or

110
00:05:18.392 --> 00:05:19.458
right was less or more.

111
00:05:19.458 --> 00:05:23.010
I would have gone with left less and
right being higher.

112
00:05:23.010 --> 00:05:25.420
That's just me, but then again,
you know, what can I tell you?

113
00:05:25.420 --> 00:05:27.688
I don't eat cheeseburgers, so for
me it wouldn't actually matter.

114
00:05:27.688 --> 00:05:28.691
But I get the idea.

115
00:05:28.691 --> 00:05:29.270
You're absolutely right.

116
00:05:29.270 --> 00:05:31.530
It would be something along those lines,
right?

117
00:05:31.530 --> 00:05:33.536
Less filling, or
rather equally filling but

118
00:05:33.536 --> 00:05:35.496
less cost is what we
were going after there.

119
00:05:35.496 --> 00:05:38.020
>> [LAUGH]
>> I've never actually explained routing

120
00:05:38.020 --> 00:05:40.060
with a reference to nutrition.

121
00:05:40.060 --> 00:05:41.580
>> It was just kind of on the fly.

122
00:05:41.580 --> 00:05:43.187
So sorry if it doesn't make sense.

123
00:05:43.187 --> 00:05:43.919
>> It was.

124
00:05:43.919 --> 00:05:44.860
>> But that's just how it works sometimes.

125
00:05:44.860 --> 00:05:48.230
>> But that's the beautiful thing about
having Cherokee hosting with me here.

126
00:05:48.230 --> 00:05:49.460
>> We always never know.

127
00:05:49.460 --> 00:05:52.880
There's always a surprise element
in the explanations that we get.

128
00:05:52.880 --> 00:05:53.896
But I actually like that one.

129
00:05:53.896 --> 00:05:56.460
That is kind of a cool way of
thinking about it, all kidding aside.

130
00:05:56.460 --> 00:06:00.450
So when we think about our routing table,
right, we are seeing that every machine,

131
00:06:00.450 --> 00:06:04.150
and this is just a server 16 machine,
right, just out of the box installed.

132
00:06:04.150 --> 00:06:05.580
Nothing special about it,

00:06:05.580 --> 00:06:08.470

134
00:06:08.470 --> 00:06:10.460
>> These are gonna
represent default routes,

135
00:06:10.460 --> 00:06:12.640
the routes that we have to have
knowledge of and be aware of.

136
00:06:12.640 --> 00:06:14.970
And then we may add to this
depending on what we're doing.

137
00:06:14.970 --> 00:06:19.003
So we've got our starting network
destination of all zeroes here, right,

138
00:06:19.003 --> 00:06:21.596
that we've got our loop back, adapter 127.

139
00:06:21.596 --> 00:06:25.509
We've got the broadcast, right,
end of the block there for 127,

140
00:06:25.509 --> 00:06:28.378
we gotta repair the block,
we've looked at that.

141
00:06:28.378 --> 00:06:31.339
We've got a 192.168 block
which is our actual

142
00:06:31.339 --> 00:06:35.306
interface address that's a sign
that's what we're actually using.

143
00:06:35.306 --> 00:06:38.050
We're on the 192.168 network,
so we have that.

144
00:06:38.050 --> 00:06:43.040
We have our 224 address block here,
this is our multitask and our broadcast,

145
00:06:43.040 --> 00:06:44.530
all 255 blocks here.

146
00:06:44.530 --> 00:06:47.960
So all of these are going to specify and
dictate for

147
00:06:47.960 --> 00:06:51.160
us certain basic elements that we
need to understand to use networking.

148
00:06:51.160 --> 00:06:55.280
And then we add in and
configure them on the fly if necessary.

149
00:06:55.280 --> 00:06:57.630
Now what I'm gonna do is I'm
gonna switch over here for

150
00:06:57.630 --> 00:06:59.940

151
00:06:59.940 --> 00:07:02.830
So just bear with me here while
I change our console out.

152
00:07:02.830 --> 00:07:04.490
And I promised you that
we would talk about yet

00:07:04.490 --> 00:07:08.390

154
00:07:08.390 --> 00:07:11.510
It's often overlooked cuz a lot of
times we don't have a Routing and

155
00:07:11.510 --> 00:07:13.920
Remote Access configuration running.

00:07:13.920 --> 00:07:17.390
And so we may not think of the fact
that the RRAS, or Routing and

157
00:07:17.390 --> 00:07:22.795
Remote Access, MMC, or Management Console,
can also be used in this regard.

158
00:07:22.795 --> 00:07:24.281
But it is available to us and

159
00:07:24.281 --> 00:07:27.520

up a RRAS server in Server 16.

160
00:07:27.520 --> 00:07:32.835
Just went in to the Server Manager,

00:07:32.835 --> 00:07:37.323

00:04:21.410 --> 00:04:22.650
>> That is absolutely right.

00:04:22.650 --> 00:04:24.786
It just an understanding that

00:04:24.786 --> 00:04:26.350

00:04:26.350 --> 00:04:27.470

00:04:37.270 --> 00:04:41.760

00:04:41.760 --> 00:04:43.710

00:04:43.710 --> 00:04:47.090

00:04:47.090 --> 00:04:48.910

98
00:04:48.910 --> 00:04:50.120
I can trust that response.

99
00:04:50.120 --> 00:04:52.960
He's also telling me that

100
00:04:52.960 --> 00:04:54.010
I'm good to go.

101
00:04:54.010 --> 00:04:56.460
It's when I get a response

102
00:04:56.460 --> 00:04:59.390
I hope it's from my DNS server,

103
00:04:59.390 --> 00:05:01.650
I could've been redirected

00:05:01.650 --> 00:05:03.560

105
00:05:03.560 --> 00:05:08.000
Somebody could've messed with the cache

106
00:05:08.000 --> 00:05:09.510
If we don't sign this stuff,

107
00:05:09.510 --> 00:05:11.925

108
00:05:11.925 --> 00:05:14.175
Securing a DNS zone by using signing.

But again, it's the individual records.

validation support without changing

So, it's really neat that we can do this,

00:06:20.200 --> 00:06:22.020

131
00:06:22.020 --> 00:06:23.180
So, how does it work?

132

Keep in mind, we're not signing the zone

A couple of things we're gonna need to

00:06:58.060 --> 00:06:59.810

00:08:13.140 --> 00:08:14.660

177
00:08:38.120 --> 00:08:39.510
So what is DNS supposed to do?

178
00:08:39.510 --> 00:08:45.600
How can I validate the name

00:08:45.600 --> 00:08:51.920
Cuz I can do a DOS attack on you by

00:08:51.920 --> 00:08:54.110
West is trying to connect

00:09:02.380 --> 00:09:04.900
That name doesn't exist, even though

187
00:09:04.900 --> 00:09:06.320
You can't connect to it, right?

188
00:09:06.320 --> 00:09:09.640
So we need some way to also respond
when there is no record and

189
00:09:09.640 --> 00:09:10.990
there is no signature.

190
00:09:10.990 --> 00:09:15.200
And that's what NSEC is all about is
the next secure, is what it's short for.

191
00:09:15.200 --> 00:09:21.070
And it allows me to have some kind of
response for when names don't exist.

192
00:09:21.070 --> 00:09:23.460
>> You know you're talking about
signatures and cryptology and

00:09:23.460 --> 00:09:26.350
one of the things I kind of understand
a little bit about the cryptology part is

00:09:26.350 --> 00:09:28.080
there's got to be some kind of key.

00:09:28.080 --> 00:09:30.010
Some kind of a not an encryption, but

196
00:09:30.010 --> 00:09:32.905
some kind of key that helps us to
do this digital signature, right?

197
00:09:32.905 --> 00:09:35.110
>> Mm-hm.
There's several keys, and

198
00:09:35.110 --> 00:09:38.030
jump right back to NSEC3 real quick.

199
00:09:38.030 --> 00:09:43.400
NSEC3 is better than NSEC because it
prevents something called zone walking.

200
00:09:43.400 --> 00:09:48.070
All right, with NSEC it worked, it was
able to provide a response when there was

00:09:48.070 --> 00:09:50.370
no record and

00:09:50.370 --> 00:09:53.950
But the problem was the bad guys figured
out how they could start enumerating my

from all different names and

there it goes, right?

514
00:29:29.140 --> 00:29:31.610
Now, wait a second then we just say,

515
00:29:31.610 --> 00:29:37.020
Wes, that to get a secondary I had to have
permission to get a copy of the zone file.

516
00:29:37.020 --> 00:29:38.620
Here I didn't need it, did I?

517
00:29:38.620 --> 00:29:41.090
Because I'm not getting
their entire zone file.

518
00:29:41.090 --> 00:29:43.460
I'm only getting publicly
available information.

519
00:29:43.460 --> 00:29:47.560
I'm getting the IP address of
their DNS Servers then that's it.

520
00:29:47.560 --> 00:29:51.730
Now I can talk to their DNS Servers and
get the rest of the information.

521
00:29:51.730 --> 00:29:54.040
But I'm not replicating
their entire zone file.

522
00:29:54.040 --> 00:29:59.740
So to set up a stub zone you don't need
permission from that other namespace.

523
00:29:59.740 --> 00:30:03.280
You can set it up and it'll just
replicate that information over.

524
00:30:03.280 --> 00:30:06.590
These are known as glue records in case
they ask you that on the question.

525
00:30:06.590 --> 00:30:09.910
On the test [LAUGH] if they
ask you that on the question.

526
00:30:09.910 --> 00:30:11.300
Yeah, that's a good one.

527
00:30:11.300 --> 00:30:15.470
If they ask you on the exam what
information is included in a stub zone

528
00:30:15.470 --> 00:30:17.620
it's what we call the glue records.

529
00:30:17.620 --> 00:30:18.800
Yes, like Elmer's.

530
00:30:18.800 --> 00:30:19.950
The glue records.

531
00:30:19.950 --> 00:30:22.310
You're gonna get the A record for

532
00:30:22.310 --> 00:30:26.270
their name servers and
the NS record for their name servers.

533
00:30:26.270 --> 00:30:28.330
And the SOA, the start of authority.

534
00:30:28.330 --> 00:30:32.330
We'll learn about what these records are
in just a couple of episodes coming up.

535
00:30:32.330 --> 00:30:34.200
But the SOA, the start of authority.

536
00:30:34.200 --> 00:30:38.170
And then for each name server they have
you'll get an A record and an NS record.

537
00:30:38.170 --> 00:30:40.070
All right, and those will be updated.

538
00:30:40.070 --> 00:30:44.870
Every time, periodically, my server is
gonna call out to their DNS Server and

539
00:30:44.870 --> 00:30:46.590
say, hey, has anything changed?

540
00:30:46.590 --> 00:30:49.840
And if any of their DNS Server's IP
addresses have changed, that information

541
00:30:49.840 --> 00:30:54.400
will get updated and we'll always be
able to connect to their DNS Servers.

542
00:30:54.400 --> 00:30:58.970
Dynamic conditional forwarding is
really what stubs zones is all about.

543
00:30:58.970 --> 00:31:00.850
>> Well, Mike, thanks,
that's a lot of information.

544
00:31:00.850 --> 00:31:04.614
And thank you for taking a complex topic
and breaking it down a little bit now

545
00:31:04.614 --> 00:31:07.921
I know we have more to go in our
topics here inside of this episode.

546
00:31:07.921 --> 00:31:11.349
But looks like we're coming to the end
of another episode so, Mike do you have

547
00:31:11.349 --> 00:31:15.040
anything else you would like to throw in
this one or are we going for a par 2?

548
00:31:15.040 --> 00:31:17.950
>> I have a ton of stuff but
we're short on time.

549
00:31:17.950 --> 00:31:19.810
So, we'll come back for another one.

550
00:31:19.810 --> 00:31:21.620
>> All right,
Mike well we appreciate you being here and

551
00:31:21.620 --> 00:31:23.270
we appreciate you the viewer watching.

552
00:31:23.270 --> 00:31:24.910
Signing out for ITPROTV.

553
00:31:24.910 --> 00:31:27.160
I've been your host, Wes Bryan
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

554
00:31:27.160 --> 00:31:29.618
>> And we'll see you next time.

555
00:31:29.618 --> 00:31:35.613
[MUSIC]

556
00:31:35.613 --> 00:31:37.430
>> Thank you for watching ITPROTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their exploration of DNS zones and records. They look at how to resolve single label names through GlobalNames zones. They explain how to generate zone statistics for diagnostics and maintenance of DNS zones. Finally they will look at the different records that can be contained inside of a DNS zone
episodes.title: DNS Zones and Records Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.109
Welcome to IT Pro TV,
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:02.109 --> 00:00:08.426
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.426 --> 00:00:11.611
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:11.611 --> 00:00:14.281
>> Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at IT Pro TV.

5
00:00:14.281 --> 00:00:15.935
I'm your host Wes Bryan.

6
00:00:15.935 --> 00:00:19.266
In today's episode we're continuing
along that journey that is

7
00:00:19.266 --> 00:00:23.689
the networking with Windows Server 2016,
and just when you thought we were done,

8
00:00:23.689 --> 00:00:25.097
we're back with more DNS.

9
00:00:25.097 --> 00:00:27.464
And it kinda shows you
how important it is and

10
00:00:27.464 --> 00:00:30.219
how much you need to pay
attention on it in the exam.

11
00:00:30.219 --> 00:00:31.883
So joining us back again is none
other than Mr Mike Rodrick.

12
00:00:31.883 --> 00:00:33.259
Mike, how are you doing sir?

13
00:00:33.259 --> 00:00:34.139
>> Doing great.

14
00:00:34.139 --> 00:00:35.427
Thanks for having me back, and yeah,

15
00:00:35.427 --> 00:00:37.247
continuing with my favorite subject,
good old DNS.

16
00:00:37.247 --> 00:00:39.801
So we got a few more
things we need to discuss.

17
00:00:39.801 --> 00:00:41.352
We've looked at a lot of it already.

18
00:00:41.352 --> 00:00:44.093
Installation configuring of
the DNS servers themselves.

19
00:00:44.093 --> 00:00:47.575
We talked about zones, zone types,
Active Directory integrated,

20
00:00:47.575 --> 00:00:48.843
a lot of that good stuff.

21
00:00:48.843 --> 00:00:53.121
Now we're gonna take a look more at
some of the things we do inside DNS

22
00:00:53.121 --> 00:00:55.085
to make name resolution work.

23
00:00:55.085 --> 00:00:56.475
>> You know, speaking of zones,

24
00:00:56.475 --> 00:00:58.831
you showed us a few of those
zones in a prior episode.

25
00:00:58.831 --> 00:01:00.063
We looked at what?

26
00:01:00.063 --> 00:01:02.241
If I can recap and
remember this right, primary zones.

27
00:01:02.241 --> 00:01:03.711
We looked at secondary zones.

28
00:01:03.711 --> 00:01:06.415
We looked at stub zones as well.

29
00:01:06.415 --> 00:01:09.117
Do we have any other zones here or
we covered it?

30
00:01:09.117 --> 00:01:11.961
>> We do, we've got a new one,
or I shouldn't say a new one,

31
00:01:11.961 --> 00:01:13.597
we've got another one to cover.

32
00:01:13.597 --> 00:01:16.815
And that is out GlobalNames Zone.

33
00:01:16.815 --> 00:01:19.437
And GlobalNames Zones
is an interesting one.

34
00:01:19.437 --> 00:01:24.215
The idea behind GlobalNames Zones is it
allows me to resolve what we would call

35
00:01:24.215 --> 00:01:26.063
single label names, right?

36
00:01:26.063 --> 00:01:31.916
We know a node, a computer,
a device has a name like serv01 or

37
00:01:31.916 --> 00:01:37.666
file02 or dc01 or Client 25 or
whatever the case may be.

38
00:01:37.666 --> 00:01:39.555
We give our machines names, and

39
00:01:39.555 --> 00:01:43.482
then we take our DNS suffix when
those machines belong to a domain.

40
00:01:43.482 --> 00:01:46.182
We take that DNS suffix like lab.itpro.tv.

41
00:01:46.182 --> 00:01:52.043
We plug it together with the host name and
we get client25.lab.itpro.tv and

42
00:01:52.043 --> 00:01:56.541
that's known as the FQDN or
the fully qualified domain name.

43
00:01:56.541 --> 00:02:01.215
And the way DNS works is it needs
the FQDN to be able to resolve a name

44
00:02:01.215 --> 00:02:02.661
into an IP address.

45
00:02:02.661 --> 00:02:06.539
And you might think well wait Mike,
I don't always type in the full name.

46
00:02:06.539 --> 00:02:10.199
When I'm going to file server 01,
I type file 01 and it goes there,

47
00:02:10.199 --> 00:02:11.364
how is that possible?

48
00:02:11.364 --> 00:02:15.610
And that's the way DNS works,
is it take the DNS suffix for the node.

49
00:02:15.610 --> 00:02:19.798
If you don't type a fully qualified domain
name, it has to make some assumptions.

50
00:02:19.798 --> 00:02:23.908
And it says all right, most likely the
resource that you're trying to get to is

51
00:02:23.908 --> 00:02:25.292
in the same domain as you.

52
00:02:25.292 --> 00:02:29.960
So I'm gonna use your host, your nodes,
DNS suffix, plug it in with the name that

53
00:02:29.960 --> 00:02:33.154
you've typed, and
probably be able to find that name.

54
00:02:33.154 --> 00:02:35.271
Cuz without the fully
qualified domain name,

55
00:02:35.271 --> 00:02:37.342
how do I know what DNS server to go to,
right?

56
00:02:37.342 --> 00:02:41.157
We talked about route, .com, and

57
00:02:41.157 --> 00:02:46.768
then Contoso.com or
root.tv itpro.tv, right?

58
00:02:46.768 --> 00:02:50.575
So how would I know what server to
go to if you just told me client 25.

59
00:02:50.575 --> 00:02:52.563
Is that client25.google.com?

60
00:02:52.563 --> 00:02:55.323
Is that client25.lab.itpro.tv?

61
00:02:55.323 --> 00:02:56.717
What the heck is it?

62
00:02:56.717 --> 00:03:01.184
So DNS makes some assumptions,
plugs us together and tries it that way.

63
00:03:01.184 --> 00:03:04.036
>> So you've been saying that if I
understand it right is a higher rate,

64
00:03:04.036 --> 00:03:05.658
a higher article name space right, and

65
00:03:05.658 --> 00:03:07.790
you have divisions in those
different levels now.

66
00:03:07.790 --> 00:03:08.699
How does that come?

67
00:03:08.699 --> 00:03:12.326
What would be the contrast if we're
looking at a GlobalName Zone?

68
00:03:12.326 --> 00:03:14.611
What are we looking at that would be
different than that hierarchical approach?

69
00:03:14.611 --> 00:03:17.061
>> Well GlobalName Zone is
a flat namespace, right?

70
00:03:17.061 --> 00:03:20.828
And this goes back to we've had
flat naming conventions before,

71
00:03:20.828 --> 00:03:22.271
there's still around.

72
00:03:22.271 --> 00:03:26.475
They’ve been telling us they're gonna
go away forever but we have nNet BIOS,

73
00:03:26.475 --> 00:03:28.777
right, which is a flat naming structure.

74
00:03:28.777 --> 00:03:33.499
When you install Windows for example,
you still give your node a Net BIOS name.

75
00:03:33.499 --> 00:03:37.965
It just takes the first characters of
whatever your host name is gonna be, and

76
00:03:37.965 --> 00:03:42.721
uses that for the Net BIOS name, cuz Net
BIOS is still used by older applications.

77
00:03:42.721 --> 00:03:46.146
And so for backwards compatibility,
it's still around.

78
00:03:46.146 --> 00:03:48.493
But it was limited because of
the fact that it was flat.

79
00:03:48.493 --> 00:03:50.343
There was not dot this, that, the other.

80
00:03:50.343 --> 00:03:56.461
It’s just client 25, which is very
limiting because that has to be unique.

81
00:03:56.461 --> 00:03:59.500
So I'm already limited by the number
of names I can come up with,

82
00:03:59.500 --> 00:04:01.936
with the note-character
limitation that I have.

83
00:04:01.936 --> 00:04:04.182
I couldn't come up with
a global unique name for

84
00:04:04.182 --> 00:04:06.108
every single device out there, right?

85
00:04:06.108 --> 00:04:08.125
So, Net BIOS is not routable.

86
00:04:08.125 --> 00:04:11.479
It’s not used, but
internally on your internal network.

87
00:04:11.479 --> 00:04:14.548
>> Now Mike, I know that you've,
I'm going to age Mike here for a second.

88
00:04:14.548 --> 00:04:17.268
I know you've definitely had to
deal with Net BIOS in your days.

89
00:04:17.268 --> 00:04:21.011
Now if I remember right, it also had
the tendency to give you some performance

90
00:04:21.011 --> 00:04:24.998
degradation on your networks, because
it was always broadcast communication.

91
00:04:24.998 --> 00:04:27.781
So everybody's trying to find this by
basically standing up in the middle of

92
00:04:27.781 --> 00:04:29.484
the room and
yelling at the top of their lungs.

93
00:04:29.484 --> 00:04:30.426
Is this a little bit different?

94
00:04:30.426 --> 00:04:32.178
Are we asking a direct
question of a dns server, or

95
00:04:32.178 --> 00:04:34.702
are we still getting up on the table and
shouting at the top of our lungs?

96
00:04:34.702 --> 00:04:37.564
>> It's definitely different, and
that's a great point in a Net BIOS.

97
00:04:37.564 --> 00:04:41.074
One of the downsides of Net BIOS was what
we call a noisy protocol because it did

98
00:04:41.074 --> 00:04:43.456
generate a lot of broadcast
traffic on the network.

99
00:04:43.456 --> 00:04:45.690
And we had ways to deal with that.

100
00:04:45.690 --> 00:04:49.788
We had what was called a WIN server,
a Windows Internet Name server,

101
00:04:49.788 --> 00:04:52.487
that we could install,
a role just like DNS.

102
00:04:52.487 --> 00:04:54.376
That would basically do
the same thing as DNS.

103
00:04:54.376 --> 00:04:58.602
It was a little database of NetBIOS
names to IP address mappings and, so,

104
00:04:58.602 --> 00:05:02.625
instead of just hollering out,
you could connect to the WINSserver,

105
00:05:02.625 --> 00:05:07.219
say what's the IP address of client 25,
and it could tell you the IP address.

106
00:05:07.219 --> 00:05:12.346
The idea behind GlobalName Zones is we
knew Net BIOS was going away eventually,

107
00:05:12.346 --> 00:05:17.472
it's not used very much, and having two
different name resolution services,

108
00:05:17.472 --> 00:05:21.449
having to run DNS and having to
run WINS to support both of these

109
00:05:21.449 --> 00:05:24.610
name resolution protocols,
was unnecessary.

110
00:05:24.610 --> 00:05:26.268
DNS is where we wanna be.

111
00:05:26.268 --> 00:05:29.542
So Microsoft said,
well tell you what we're gonna do,

112
00:05:29.542 --> 00:05:31.848
we're gonna add a new zone type to DNS.

113
00:05:31.848 --> 00:05:36.520
We'll call it GlobalNames, and
we'll use it to host single label names.

114
00:05:36.520 --> 00:05:41.814
And we can use that and
try to get rid of our dependency on WINS.

115
00:05:41.814 --> 00:05:46.707
So we can use GlobalNames basically as
a single label name that functions very

116
00:05:46.707 --> 00:05:50.395
similar to WINS that allows you
to have one name resolution

117
00:05:50.395 --> 00:05:52.822
solution rather than have to do both.

118
00:05:52.822 --> 00:05:56.432
I can do it all within DNS and
I can get rid of my WIN servers.

119
00:05:56.432 --> 00:05:58.200
>> And that brings me to my question.

120
00:05:58.200 --> 00:05:59.534
One of the things I was thinking about,
Mike.

121
00:05:59.534 --> 00:06:03.711
Are we looking at a replacement for WINS,
or are we talking about down at the DNA

122
00:06:03.711 --> 00:06:06.450
level, throw another acronym out of DNS,
right?

123
00:06:06.450 --> 00:06:08.988
Down at its entirety,
are they two completely separate things?

124
00:06:08.988 --> 00:06:12.031
>> Great question and
very important that we understand

125
00:06:12.031 --> 00:06:16.030
the answer to this one because it
depends on your perspective I think.

126
00:06:16.030 --> 00:06:20.375
And one way you can say GlobalName Zones
is a replacement for WINS, but

127
00:06:20.375 --> 00:06:24.436
you'd be wrong in most cases when
you say it that way, all right.

128
00:06:24.436 --> 00:06:28.534
It is intended to replace
our dependency on WINS, but

129
00:06:28.534 --> 00:06:31.729
it's not a direct replacement for WINS.

130
00:06:31.729 --> 00:06:35.699
In other words, if you have an older
application that understands NetBIOS or

131
00:06:35.699 --> 00:06:40.037
understands WINS, you can't just point
that application to the DNS server that's

132
00:06:40.037 --> 00:06:42.742
hosting the GlobalName Zones and
expect it to work.

133
00:06:42.742 --> 00:06:45.056
Completely different protocols, right?

134
00:06:45.056 --> 00:06:51.044
So, in one way,
GlobalName Zones is meant to replace WINS.

135
00:06:51.044 --> 00:06:53.359
But understand that in a technical sense,

136
00:06:53.359 --> 00:06:56.068
GlobalNames Zones is not a replacement for
WINS.

137
00:06:56.068 --> 00:06:58.948
It does the same thing as WINS,
and it will allow me to

138
00:06:58.948 --> 00:07:03.017
get rid of my WINS dependencies, but
it doesn't replace WINS directly.

139
00:07:03.017 --> 00:07:05.250
If you've application
that has to have WINS,

140
00:07:05.250 --> 00:07:07.150
you're gonna have to run a WIN server.

141
00:07:07.150 --> 00:07:09.420
You can't point it to
that GlobalName Zone.

142
00:07:09.420 --> 00:07:14.348
All right, so now let's talk about the way
it works is you have to create a new zone.

143
00:07:14.348 --> 00:07:19.750
And it's not a different type of zone,
it's just a standard, it's a primary zone.

144
00:07:19.750 --> 00:07:22.369
It can be standard it can be
Active Directory integrated.

145
00:07:22.369 --> 00:07:26.483
And so when we go to create it,
we just create a new zone, same way,

146
00:07:26.483 --> 00:07:27.809
and choose primary.

147
00:07:27.809 --> 00:07:33.090
The key is to name it GlobalNames
all one word, no spaces.

148
00:07:33.090 --> 00:07:34.745
And that is plural, GlobalNames.

149
00:07:34.745 --> 00:07:38.226
Once you create that zone named,
GlobalNames, DNS sees that and

150
00:07:38.226 --> 00:07:42.548
we have to turn on the functionality for
it because it's not enabled by default.

151
00:07:42.548 --> 00:07:46.859
Once we turn that on, and
it sees that zone it will start using it.

152
00:07:46.859 --> 00:07:50.462
Now within that zone,
we have to manually create the records.

153
00:07:50.462 --> 00:07:54.812
There's no dynamic updates, or
anything like that for GlobalName Zones.

154
00:07:54.812 --> 00:07:56.519
You have to go in and create them.

155
00:07:56.519 --> 00:08:00.411
And the records you create within your
global name zones are gonna be CNAME

156
00:08:00.411 --> 00:08:01.130
records.

157
00:08:01.130 --> 00:08:03.216
Now, we haven't talked about all
the different types of records yet,

158
00:08:03.216 --> 00:08:04.279
that's coming up in this episode.

159
00:08:04.279 --> 00:08:07.090
But a CNAME record is basically an alias.

160
00:08:07.090 --> 00:08:11.651
And so, what that means is, and
let's talk about, actually,

161
00:08:11.651 --> 00:08:13.625
why we would do this first.

162
00:08:13.625 --> 00:08:18.060
If I've got a file server, and
in order to connect to that file server,

163
00:08:18.060 --> 00:08:24.952
people had to type in, http:, or ftp:,
or whatever they're trying to do,

164
00:08:24.952 --> 00:08:32.010
file01.east.lab.itpro.tv to
connect to this site, right?

165
00:08:32.010 --> 00:08:33.752
What I can do is, I can say,
I'm gonna make it easy on my users.

166
00:08:33.752 --> 00:08:39.614
I'm gonna make a single label
name called files or data 01.

167
00:08:39.614 --> 00:08:43.689
And then what I'm gonna do is
I'm going to make a C name, or

168
00:08:43.689 --> 00:08:49.612
an alias record that says the data1
is actually file01.eas.lab.itpro.tv.

169
00:08:49.612 --> 00:08:54.201
And now my users can use that single short
little name that's easy to remember,

170
00:08:54.201 --> 00:08:58.480
instead of that big old long fully
qualified domain name, right?

171
00:08:58.480 --> 00:09:02.130
That was an advantage of netBios, it was
names were short and easy to remember.

172
00:09:02.130 --> 00:09:03.550
So, that's what global names lets us do.

173
00:09:03.550 --> 00:09:05.470
We create these single label names for

174
00:09:05.470 --> 00:09:07.990
resources that we want our
users to connect to, or

175
00:09:07.990 --> 00:09:12.390
apps to connect to without having to
use that fully qualified domain name.

176
00:09:12.390 --> 00:09:17.320
>> Now Mike, I know that things like the
DNS client is built into your operating

177
00:09:17.320 --> 00:09:19.990
system, and let me kind of reiterate
something that Mike's already said, so

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their exploration of DNS zones and records. They explain pointer records called PTR records and reverse lookup zones. They will discuss how to keep the DNS zone database healthy through aging and scavenging of old DNS records as well as configuring the  time-to-live or TTLs on DNS records.

we don't have to worry about my gosh,

373
00:18:50.430 --> 00:18:52.280
we're never gonna get that record back.

374
00:18:52.280 --> 00:18:54.867
>> Speaking of records and
we talked about time, right.

375
00:18:54.867 --> 00:18:56.310
Everything's about time here.

376
00:18:56.310 --> 00:19:00.560
Do we have other characteristics of
records that we have to worry about when

377
00:19:00.560 --> 00:19:01.800
it comes to time?

378
00:19:01.800 --> 00:19:03.220
>> We do and before we get there though,

379
00:19:03.220 --> 00:19:05.450
I do want to go back one more
second to aging and scavenging.

380
00:19:05.450 --> 00:19:06.960
Let's just pull up my screen here.

381
00:19:06.960 --> 00:19:12.180
So, now you understand what these values
mean, why would I change them, right?

382
00:19:12.180 --> 00:19:14.440
Well, cuz you can see,
it's meant to be changed.

383
00:19:14.440 --> 00:19:16.440
This is just the default.

384
00:19:16.440 --> 00:19:19.760
And the idea here is in
a dynamic environment,

385
00:19:19.760 --> 00:19:21.690
seven days is a long time to wait.

386
00:19:21.690 --> 00:19:25.250
It's a long time to have those
stale records sitting there.

387
00:19:25.250 --> 00:19:27.430
DNS is replicating every 15 minutes.

388
00:19:27.430 --> 00:19:29.600
I'm replicating unnecessary information.

389
00:19:29.600 --> 00:19:33.890
In a relatively static environment,
this causes me no problems.

390
00:19:33.890 --> 00:19:37.770
But in a dynamic environment,
we might wanna speed this up a little bit.

391
00:19:37.770 --> 00:19:42.390
We might say,
you know what let's do three and

392
00:19:42.390 --> 00:19:44.570
three and
they don't have to be the same either.

393
00:19:44.570 --> 00:19:46.690
I'm just doing that from habit.

394
00:19:47.820 --> 00:19:50.680
They don't have to be the same,
so you can change those values,

395
00:19:50.680 --> 00:19:54.610
you can even change them to hours if
you want it to be really really fast.

396
00:19:54.610 --> 00:19:55.260
Now let's take a look, so

397
00:19:55.260 --> 00:19:58.870
I'm gonna set it at the zone level,
I mean sorry at the server level.

398
00:20:00.260 --> 00:20:01.510
Here's the option.

399
00:20:01.510 --> 00:20:04.830
Do I wanna apply these settings to
existing Active Directory zones?

00:20:04.830 --> 00:20:09.255
If I don't check that and I click OK,
and we go and create a new zone.

401
00:20:09.255 --> 00:20:11.020
Right-click, New Zone.

402
00:20:11.020 --> 00:20:12.870
And I just real quick run through here.

403
00:20:12.870 --> 00:20:15.510
Primary, blah, blah,
blah, blah, call it ASDF.

404
00:20:16.690 --> 00:20:18.150
Yep, yep, yep, yep, yep.

405
00:20:18.150 --> 00:20:21.110
And we look at the properties
of this new zone I just created.

406
00:20:22.760 --> 00:20:24.060
Now we go to Aging.

407
00:20:24.060 --> 00:20:27.250
Look, it's already turned on and

00:20:27.250 --> 00:20:31.236
If we go to the properties of that zone

00:20:34.638 --> 00:20:36.820
Notice it's not turned on, all right?

00:20:36.820 --> 00:20:39.040
So that check mark would've

00:20:39.040 --> 00:20:42.730

The other one I wanted to

Standard primary,

So I'm going to uncheck

Make a little file, we'll do secure and

Finish and I will take a look

00:21:19.190 --> 00:21:22.100

Standard for zones have been around

they just don't understand it.

So you do have to,

you have to manually turn it on,

428
00:21:36.100 --> 00:21:37.820
All right, next thing is TTL.

429
00:21:37.820 --> 00:21:41.590
Wes was gonna hit in there about
something else that is time related.

430
00:21:41.590 --> 00:21:45.690
And that is our TTL, or Time To Live.

431
00:21:45.690 --> 00:21:50.130
In order to understand that,
we really need to understand caching.

432
00:21:50.130 --> 00:21:51.966
And so we'll briefly hit caching here,

433
00:21:51.966 --> 00:21:54.830
we're going to cover it again
in another episode, I'm sure.

434
00:21:54.830 --> 00:22:02.540
But caching is storing or
temporarily storing information.

435
00:22:02.540 --> 00:22:03.640
When you hear the word cache,

436
00:22:03.640 --> 00:22:08.440
not like the money, but
C-A-C-H-E think temporary storage, right.

437
00:22:08.440 --> 00:22:13.410
We talk about cache memory and
other things, as always temporary.

438
00:22:13.410 --> 00:22:16.219
Well, when a DNS server gets a response,

439
00:22:16.219 --> 00:22:20.930
let's say that I type in
www.microsoft.com in my browser.

440
00:22:20.930 --> 00:22:25.330
My client sends a query to my
DNS server here on my network

441
00:22:25.330 --> 00:22:27.820
says what's the IP
address of Microsoft.com?

442
00:22:27.820 --> 00:22:30.810
He doesn't know, so
he goes to the root and then the .com and

443
00:22:30.810 --> 00:22:35.090
then the Microsoft.com, and
my DNS server finally gets the answer, and

444
00:22:35.090 --> 00:22:39.600
it gives the answer to my client, and
my browser opens up to www.microsoft.com.

445
00:22:39.600 --> 00:22:44.110
But the server, after he gave that
answer to me, he also cached the answer.

446
00:22:44.110 --> 00:22:45.440
He stored it.

447
00:22:45.440 --> 00:22:49.490
That way of Wes, two seconds later,
also opens up a browser and

448
00:22:49.490 --> 00:22:51.020
goes to Mircrosoft.com.

449
00:22:51.020 --> 00:22:53.200
It sends a query to my local DNS server.

450
00:22:53.200 --> 00:22:56.580
My DNS server says,
I don't know I'll go out and wait.

451
00:22:56.580 --> 00:23:00.550
I just got that answer from Mike,
hasn't change in the last five seconds,

452
00:23:00.550 --> 00:23:02.560
I'll just give that to you, right.

453
00:23:02.560 --> 00:23:05.780
So it speeds up the the process,
that's what caching is for.

454
00:23:05.780 --> 00:23:08.810
Now how long does the server cache it for?

455
00:23:08.810 --> 00:23:12.670
That's determined by the TTL or
the time to live on the record.

456
00:23:12.670 --> 00:23:16.500
When Microsoft's DNS server sent
the answer back to my DNS server,

457
00:23:16.500 --> 00:23:20.130
included in the answer was the name and
the IP address of their web server and

458
00:23:20.130 --> 00:23:23.040
it was also a TTL value, a time to live.

459
00:23:23.040 --> 00:23:26.750
My server will cache it for
whatever that TTL says.

460
00:23:26.750 --> 00:23:29.450
Once that TTL expires, it goes away.

461
00:23:29.450 --> 00:23:32.650
We're gonna throw that cache record
out and if I open up a browser and

462
00:23:32.650 --> 00:23:36.150
go to Microsoft.com again, it's gonna have
to go through the whole process all over

463
00:23:36.150 --> 00:23:39.370
again, but then when it gets
the answer it'll cash it.

464
00:23:39.370 --> 00:23:40.060
You might think why,

465
00:23:40.060 --> 00:23:42.550
why do we throw it away if once
once you've cached it, keep it.

466
00:23:44.000 --> 00:23:48.000
Well that'd be great until Microsoft
changes their IP address, right?

467
00:23:48.000 --> 00:23:50.100
Now my cached entry is incorrect and

468
00:23:50.100 --> 00:23:53.800
if I'm not ever gonna go look it up again,
I'll never get the right one.

469
00:23:53.800 --> 00:23:55.430
The other one is load balancing.

470
00:23:55.430 --> 00:23:58.741
Microsoft doesn't want me hitting their
same web server every single time.

471
00:23:58.741 --> 00:24:03.037
Every time I hit DNS, they might rotate
through the IP addresses because they have

472
00:24:03.037 --> 00:24:05.411
several web servers to
handle the workload.

473
00:24:05.411 --> 00:24:08.630
If I cache one servers IP address,
and let's just say for giggles,

474
00:24:08.630 --> 00:24:11.285
most of the people here cache
the same servers address,

475
00:24:11.285 --> 00:24:13.561
they're all gonna be
hitting the same server.

476
00:24:13.561 --> 00:24:16.322
These other web servers are going to be,
hey, I don't have anything to do,

477
00:24:16.322 --> 00:24:17.457
I'll just twiddle my thumbs.

478
00:24:17.457 --> 00:24:20.875
And that one server's going,
how come I'm getting all the work?

479
00:24:20.875 --> 00:24:23.589
Because we've cached a single entry.

480
00:24:23.589 --> 00:24:27.410
So TTL controls that.

481
00:24:27.410 --> 00:24:30.830
That is determined by the server
that has the information.

482
00:24:30.830 --> 00:24:35.060
Microsoft told my DNS server how
long to keep their information for.

483
00:24:35.060 --> 00:24:37.760
When if I query for
Google if I try to go to Google,

484
00:24:37.760 --> 00:24:40.900
Google's DNS server is gonna tell me
how long to keep the information for.

485
00:24:40.900 --> 00:24:42.570
And they might be completely different.

486
00:24:42.570 --> 00:24:45.270
Microsoft might say hey cache this for
three hours.

487
00:24:45.270 --> 00:24:47.520
That way my DNS server doesn't
have to hear from you.

488
00:24:47.520 --> 00:24:52.080
You can use that same IP for three hours,
reduces the workload on my DNS server.

489
00:24:52.080 --> 00:24:54.505
Google might say, hey,
cache this for 15 seconds, right?

490
00:24:54.505 --> 00:24:56.200
Right, why?

491
00:24:56.200 --> 00:24:58.480
Because they want you to get
new IP addresses every time and

492
00:24:58.480 --> 00:25:00.220
not use the same server over and over.

493
00:25:00.220 --> 00:25:01.600
They're okay with you querying again.

494
00:25:01.600 --> 00:25:03.790
They just do something
called round robining,

495
00:25:03.790 --> 00:25:05.610
which we might come back to in a second.

496
00:25:05.610 --> 00:25:06.840
Alright.

497
00:25:06.840 --> 00:25:10.590
So TTL is set by the DNS server
that's providing the answer

498
00:25:10.590 --> 00:25:12.520
not the one that's getting the answer.

499
00:25:12.520 --> 00:25:14.720
I don't decide how long to cache it for.

500
00:25:14.720 --> 00:25:19.890
If we look at my records in here
the TTL is actually on the SOA so

501
00:25:19.890 --> 00:25:24.350
when I pull up the properties
of my zone and

502
00:25:24.350 --> 00:25:32.260
I take a look at the advanced
view which is not on here.

503
00:25:32.260 --> 00:25:35.220
Wait, sorry the SOA.

504
00:25:35.220 --> 00:25:36.208
Brain cramp for a second.

505
00:25:36.208 --> 00:25:39.927
On the SOA tab I can see the TTL.

506
00:25:39.927 --> 00:25:40.572
Right down here.

507
00:25:40.572 --> 00:25:42.841
TTL for this record is one hour.

508
00:25:42.841 --> 00:25:46.417
That's days, hours,
minutes, seconds, all right.

509
00:25:46.417 --> 00:25:53.910
The TTL for the SOA determines the TTL for
all the records in this zone, all right.

510
00:25:53.910 --> 00:25:55.970
So it becomes the default for all records.

511
00:25:55.970 --> 00:26:01.730
If I change the TTL at the SOA new
records will get that new TTL.

512
00:26:01.730 --> 00:26:04.350
The old records will not,
it does not update them.

513
00:26:04.350 --> 00:26:07.170
But any new records will
pick up that new TTL value.

514
00:26:07.170 --> 00:26:10.320
>> Is this gonna be, or does it have
to be a global configuration or

515
00:26:10.320 --> 00:26:13.200
can we get granular and do this on
an individual record there Mike?

516
00:26:13.200 --> 00:26:16.310
>> That's a great question because I
might want to really rotate through some

517
00:26:16.310 --> 00:26:21.250
records fast but others I'd rather
be static like my exchange server.

518
00:26:21.250 --> 00:26:23.900
There's only one IP address so
I want you to keep that and

519
00:26:23.900 --> 00:26:26.650
don't ask every five minutes because
the IP address isn't gonna change.

520
00:26:26.650 --> 00:26:29.440
So maybe I want you to keep that
record a little bit longer.

521
00:26:29.440 --> 00:26:32.734
But the web server records I want you
to only keep them for a few seconds and

522
00:26:32.734 --> 00:26:33.986
then throw them out right?

523
00:26:33.986 --> 00:26:37.793
So we can change the TTL on
the individual records as well.

524
00:26:37.793 --> 00:26:40.049
If I pull up the properties
of one of these records.

525
00:26:41.190 --> 00:26:41.860
All right?

526
00:26:41.860 --> 00:26:44.340
We won't see the TTL.

527
00:26:44.340 --> 00:26:45.510
Mike, you're lying to me.

528
00:26:45.510 --> 00:26:48.840
You can't change the TTL
on an individual record.

529
00:26:48.840 --> 00:26:49.760
Yes, you can.

530
00:26:49.760 --> 00:26:53.340
What you have to do is turn
on your advanced view.

531
00:26:53.340 --> 00:26:56.000
We go to the view menu on our DNS console.

532
00:26:56.000 --> 00:26:57.630
We choose advanced.

533
00:26:57.630 --> 00:27:00.282
Then we pull up the same
records properties.

534
00:27:00.282 --> 00:27:02.876
And look at there, we got a TTL.

535
00:27:02.876 --> 00:27:05.790
Notice it's one hour, all right.

536
00:27:05.790 --> 00:27:12.240
If I change the SOA TTL, so
we'll go to properties and

537
00:27:12.240 --> 00:27:20.130
we'll change the SOA TTL to two hours and
I'll apply it.

538
00:27:20.130 --> 00:27:22.010
We go look at that record again.

539
00:27:22.010 --> 00:27:23.080
It's still sitting at one hour.

540
00:27:24.090 --> 00:27:26.621
But if I make a new record.

541
00:27:26.621 --> 00:27:29.056
New host, we'll call it test.

542
00:27:29.056 --> 00:27:34.540
IP address,
10.0.100 dot some other random number.

543
00:27:34.540 --> 00:27:37.480
And we click add host,
although it did see one there.

544
00:27:37.480 --> 00:27:39.110
Let's see if it picks it up.

545
00:27:39.110 --> 00:27:39.897
It should pick it up.

546
00:27:42.495 --> 00:27:43.950
But it did not.

547
00:27:43.950 --> 00:27:48.280
For dynamically created records, if a
client was to call up and create a record,

548
00:27:48.280 --> 00:27:51.440
that would pick up the TTL from the SOA.

549
00:27:51.440 --> 00:27:54.010
If I'm manually creating it,
evidently Microsoft says, hey,

550
00:27:54.010 --> 00:27:56.660
you're a big boy,
you can set the TTL yourself.

551
00:27:56.660 --> 00:28:01.204
So [LAUGH] only dynamically created
records are gonna pick up that new default

552
00:28:01.204 --> 00:28:02.490
TTL, all right?

553
00:28:02.490 --> 00:28:03.600
So just know for the exam.

554
00:28:03.600 --> 00:28:04.700
Know what the TTL is.

555
00:28:04.700 --> 00:28:08.000
It controls how long people
are gonna cache the record for.

556
00:28:08.000 --> 00:28:10.160
And then I can change it at the SOA for

557
00:28:10.160 --> 00:28:14.755
all records, new records, new dynamically
creative records, not statics.

558
00:28:14.755 --> 00:28:18.985
And you change on individual records
if you turn on the advanced view.

559
00:28:18.985 --> 00:28:21.745
>> Now Mike,
I know we got a few more things to go

560
00:28:21.745 --> 00:28:25.805
through in here because well you
know DNS is a very big topic but

561
00:28:25.805 --> 00:28:28.625
I know that we're stretching the envelopes

562
00:28:28.625 --> 00:28:33.525
So, looks like we might have to go another
part here but before we've signed out do

563
00:28:33.525 --> 00:28:36.170
we have any additional things
you'd like to throw on this one.

564
00:28:36.170 --> 00:28:38.040
>> No.
Because I'm running out of time.

565
00:28:38.040 --> 00:28:40.540
I have too much to say, though.

566
00:28:40.540 --> 00:28:43.200
We do have a few more things I
wanna go over but I'll save it for

00:28:43.200 --> 00:28:44.320

568
00:28:44.320 --> 00:28:44.920
>> Well that's great.

569
00:28:44.920 --> 00:28:46.670
This looks like it's
good place to wrap up.

570
00:28:46.670 --> 00:28:50.058
Mike, we do appreciate you imparting
all of this wisdom to us but

571
00:28:50.058 --> 00:28:52.870
we're gonna go ahead and
sign out for ITProTV.

572
00:28:52.870 --> 00:28:54.270

573

574

topics.title: Planning and implementing an IPv4 network

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Adam introduce DHCP and explain what it does, how it happens with the DORA/ROSA process, and how to implement it in Server 2016. Specifically, Adam demonstrates installing the role, authorizing the DHCP Server, creating a scope and more!

00:19:42.096 --> 00:19:44.940
all the individual scopes that

00:19:44.940 --> 00:19:48.430

00:19:48.430 --> 00:19:51.610

00:19:51.610 --> 00:19:54.517
Referring each scope member of the super
scope is the subscope, just so

00:19:54.517 --> 00:19:55.930
you know what I was talking about.

00:19:55.930 --> 00:19:59.315
So we could drill down,
we could see that there.

00:19:59.315 --> 00:20:02.890
We can create new scopes within the super
scope container the same way we would

00:20:02.890 --> 00:20:05.480

00:20:12.306 --> 00:20:14.360

422
00:20:16.040 --> 00:20:20.120
We're just putting it into

423
00:20:20.120 --> 00:20:22.590
it's gonna be specifically tied

424
00:20:22.590 --> 00:20:24.270
It's just a matter of

00:20:24.270 --> 00:20:26.400
So just so you know.

But we have that, and you'll see we can

00:21:57.805 --> 00:22:03.298

multicast scope 1 or

00:22:08.620 --> 00:22:12.030

459
00:22:12.030 --> 00:22:16.200
Remember, the multicast range is

00:22:16.200 --> 00:22:18.530
valued for the first octet, right?

00:22:18.530 --> 00:22:22.650

So we can put in 224.0 .1.1.

00:22:27.956 --> 00:22:31.831

00:22:38.940 --> 00:22:41.145
Something like that, whatever it may be.

00:22:41.145 --> 00:22:44.255
Small scope, we don't need a lot, but

00:22:44.255 --> 00:22:47.448
We do have a TTL here that will

00:22:50.610 --> 00:22:55.110

00:22:56.590 --> 00:22:57.891

16

that's the good news.

17

We can make choices about how we secure
and protect our DHCP infrastructure.

18
00:00:45.985 --> 00:00:50.735
We can setup a DHCP cluster, traditional
clustering on Windows can be used to

19

backend our DHCP services and maintain
viability and high availability for them.

20
00:00:56.110 --> 00:00:58.630
We could set up a two
member fail over cluster.

21
00:00:58.630 --> 00:01:00.500

22

23

25
00:01:09.470 --> 00:01:13.240

26
00:01:13.240 --> 00:01:16.860
The other cluster essentially just detects
or the other member of the cluster rather

27
00:01:16.860 --> 00:01:20.450
detects the failure event and
then primary server goes down let's say.

28
00:01:20.450 --> 00:01:25.180
Our standby server detects the failure
event, activates the DHCP service.

29
00:01:25.180 --> 00:01:28.780

brings up the other instance, there's

35
00:01:48.101 --> 00:01:51.560
But however and you would then allow for

36
00:01:51.560 --> 00:01:57.170
each server to control a portion of
the overall scope so that way if one

37
00:01:57.170 --> 00:02:00.920
side of the equation was to go offline we

00:27:29.080 --> 00:27:31.280
Because it's no longer
the same IP address.

535
00:27:31.280 --> 00:27:36.240
And that's a very good example, or a real
example of how DHCP could affect you.

536
00:27:36.240 --> 00:27:38.850
>> And it just shows you
there that static assignment.

537
00:27:38.850 --> 00:27:42.340
It does have its place here
inside of our networks as

538
00:27:42.340 --> 00:27:45.430
well as dynamic making it a little
bit easier if you've got 500 clients.

539
00:27:45.430 --> 00:27:47.310
Well, I guess if you
were getting paid hourly,

540
00:27:47.310 --> 00:27:48.520
I wouldn't mind statically mapping them.

541
00:27:48.520 --> 00:27:51.940
But you guys have seen the way I type, and
you know that wouldn't go over too well.

542
00:27:51.940 --> 00:27:55.420
Mike, I know that we have just scratched
the surface when it comes to DHCP, and

543
00:27:55.420 --> 00:27:58.280
I know we got a lot more
information to come.

544
00:27:58.280 --> 00:27:59.750
Do you want to save that for
a part two, or

545
00:27:59.750 --> 00:28:01.280
you got anything else
you'd like to throw in?

546
00:28:01.280 --> 00:28:03.370
>> I do, but there is one more
thing I want to show you guys,

547
00:28:03.370 --> 00:28:09.040
let's go back over to my DHCP server and
just see what happened over here.

548
00:28:09.040 --> 00:28:12.760
If I go down to address leases and
I refresh,

549
00:28:12.760 --> 00:28:17.790
there we can see the client 01
pulled an IP address from DHCP.

550
00:28:17.790 --> 00:28:22.450
So what DHCP did was, client 01 said hey,
I need an IP address.

551
00:28:22.450 --> 00:28:27.200
DHCP here, server one, looked through this
pool, took the first available one out of

552
00:28:27.200 --> 00:28:30.380
the pool and said, here you go,
why don't you use this one?

553
00:28:30.380 --> 00:28:33.700
The client said sure,
thank you very much, I'll use that one.

554
00:28:33.700 --> 00:28:38.040
The DHCP server then writes down
who he gave that address to.

555
00:28:38.040 --> 00:28:42.590
And that one is no longer available In the
pool, he can't give the same IP address to

556
00:28:42.590 --> 00:28:46.620
two different clients otherwise we have a
conflict, so he's gonna keep track of that

557
00:28:46.620 --> 00:28:50.270
lease information and
that's what we're seeing here.

558
00:28:50.270 --> 00:28:53.400
And that is all we'll do for now,
when we come back we do have more, we'll

559
00:28:53.400 --> 00:28:56.030
start talking about some of the different
options that we have to configure cause

560
00:28:56.030 --> 00:28:58.450
we've really just scratched
the surface there.

561
00:28:58.450 --> 00:29:02.530
We also wanna take a look at
something known as reservations and

562
00:29:02.530 --> 00:29:04.130
policies as well.

563
00:29:04.130 --> 00:29:07.210
>> Well, that's a lot of great information
Mike and I guess we're gonna go ahead and

564
00:29:07.210 --> 00:29:08.290
we'll wrap it up here.

565
00:29:08.290 --> 00:29:10.170
It's been a great episode,
thank you for watching.

566
00:29:10.170 --> 00:29:13.120
Signing out for ITPRO.TV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

567
00:29:13.120 --> 00:29:14.040
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

568
00:29:14.040 --> 00:29:18.749
>> Stick around cuz we got a lot more DHCP
and networking with Windows Server 2016.

569
00:29:22.568 --> 00:29:26.778
[MUSIC]

570
00:29:26.778 --> 00:29:28.430
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.092 --> 00:00:01.365
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.365 --> 00:00:04.177
I'm your host, Don-

3
00:00:04.177 --> 00:00:06.166

00:00:06.166 --> 00:00:07.320
California [CROSSTALK]

5
00:00:07.320 --> 00:00:08.673
[MUSIC]

6
00:00:08.673 --> 00:00:12.328
>> You're watching ITProTV.

7
00:00:12.328 --> 00:00:14.989
>> Welcome back to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

8
00:00:14.989 --> 00:00:16.679
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

9
00:00:16.679 --> 00:00:17.827
And in today's episode,

10
00:00:17.827 --> 00:00:21.493
we're continuing along our journey in
networking with Windows Server 2016.

11
00:00:21.493 --> 00:00:24.275
And we've been talking about a very,
very important service.

12
00:00:24.275 --> 00:00:26.345
I'm glad to be here,
excited to be a part of it.

13
00:00:26.345 --> 00:00:28.935
Joining us back in the studios is
none other than Mr. Mike Rodrick.

14
00:00:28.935 --> 00:00:29.955
Mike, how are you doing, sir?

15
00:00:29.955 --> 00:00:31.065
>> I'm doing fantastic.

16
00:00:31.065 --> 00:00:35.345
And yeah, we're continuing on
in the wonderful world of DHCP.

17
00:00:35.345 --> 00:00:37.624
So let's just jump right back into it.

18
00:00:37.624 --> 00:00:41.420
We had finished the previous episode,
we created a scope.

19
00:00:41.420 --> 00:00:43.410
We set a couple of
the basic options in there.

20
00:00:43.410 --> 00:00:48.750
Then we took one of our clients and we
turned it into a DHCP client by choosing

21
00:00:48.750 --> 00:00:51.930
obtain an IP address and
a DNS server address automatically.

22
00:00:51.930 --> 00:00:55.060
And we saw that it was
able to pull that back.

23
00:00:55.060 --> 00:00:58.128
They don't really call it out
in the objectives anymore, but

24
00:00:58.128 --> 00:01:01.790
I do wanna mention that process just
in case they ask you on the exam.

25
00:01:01.790 --> 00:01:03.980
It's also really good when
you're troubleshooting.

26
00:01:03.980 --> 00:01:07.770
That process the client goes through
when you turn it to a DHCP client.

27
00:01:07.770 --> 00:01:11.894
So any DHCP client, when they start up or
when they need an IP address.

28
00:01:11.894 --> 00:01:16.514
There's a four-step process they go
through to obtain that configuration

29
00:01:16.514 --> 00:01:20.951
information from a DHCP server,
and it's known as DORA, D-O-R-A.

30
00:01:20.951 --> 00:01:27.000
It's discover, offer, request,
acknowledge, all right?

31
00:01:27.000 --> 00:01:31.930
So the client sends out a broadcast and
says, hey, I'm looking for a DHCP server.

32
00:01:31.930 --> 00:01:33.260
Anybody out there?

33
00:01:33.260 --> 00:01:37.440
That's the discover, I need to discover
the DHCP servers on the network.

34
00:01:37.440 --> 00:01:42.040
All DHCP servers that hear that broadcast,
they're programmed to respond to it.

35
00:01:42.040 --> 00:01:46.250
That's their job in life,
is to listen for that discover packet and

36
00:01:46.250 --> 00:01:49.230
respond to it with what we call an offer.

37
00:01:49.230 --> 00:01:53.760
Let me take one of the addresses out of my
pool, wrap it up in a nice little bow, and

38
00:01:53.760 --> 00:01:57.450
say, here you go,
here's an IP address that you could use.

39
00:01:57.450 --> 00:01:59.140
The client might get more than one offer.

40
00:01:59.140 --> 00:02:03.250
If there's more than one server on
the network that's supplying addresses,

41
00:02:03.250 --> 00:02:04.670
it could get more than one offer.

42
00:02:04.670 --> 00:02:06.810
So he's got all these offers coming in.

43
00:02:06.810 --> 00:02:11.770
The client doesn't look at him and go,
ooh, this one's odd, this one's even.

44
00:02:11.770 --> 00:02:15.062
I like odd numbers better,
I'll take this IP address.

45
00:02:15.062 --> 00:02:18.580
The first offer that gets to him
is the one he's going to take.

46
00:02:18.580 --> 00:02:22.633
So whichever server was faster, usually
we're talking about physical proximity,

47
00:02:22.633 --> 00:02:23.430
wire distance.

48
00:02:24.900 --> 00:02:25.890
So that's the offer.

49
00:02:25.890 --> 00:02:31.410
The client takes that first offer and
requests, it says, hey, I got your offer.

50
00:02:31.410 --> 00:02:34.420
I would like to use this if I can,
I want this address.

51
00:02:34.420 --> 00:02:36.980
It's still not the client's yet, okay?

52
00:02:36.980 --> 00:02:39.120
It's still in the pending stage.

53
00:02:39.120 --> 00:02:42.600
He says, I got your offer and I wanna
request it, I wanna start using it.

54
00:02:42.600 --> 00:02:44.940
That's the R in DORA, the request.

55
00:02:44.940 --> 00:02:48.170
So he sends that request back
to the offering DHCP services.

56
00:02:48.170 --> 00:02:49.870
I got it, I wanna use it.

57
00:02:49.870 --> 00:02:52.420
The server says, all right,
I'm gonna mark you down.

58
00:02:52.420 --> 00:02:54.320
It's yours, you can now start using it.

59
00:02:54.320 --> 00:02:55.340
That's the acknowledgement.

60
00:02:55.340 --> 00:02:58.060
So D-O-R-A, DORA, four-step process.

61
00:02:58.060 --> 00:03:00.650
If you wanna see it,
it's actually very easy to see.

62
00:03:00.650 --> 00:03:05.567
In your little practice labs, fire up
your DHCP server, fire up your client,

63
00:03:05.567 --> 00:03:07.584
fire up Wireshark, all right.

64
00:03:07.584 --> 00:03:12.370
On your DHCP server or the other end,
it doesn't really matter which end.

65
00:03:12.370 --> 00:03:14.310
And start capturing packets, and

66
00:03:14.310 --> 00:03:17.950
then do an ipconfig release
renew to start that process up.

67
00:03:17.950 --> 00:03:21.150
And you'll see those four packets
in that order, the discover,

68
00:03:21.150 --> 00:03:22.880
the offer, the request,
the acknowledgement.

69
00:03:22.880 --> 00:03:24.650
It's really cool to see.

70
00:03:24.650 --> 00:03:27.490
All right, so anyway,
we got that basics out of there.

71
00:03:27.490 --> 00:03:30.413
Now the next thing I wanna talk about,
so we've given it an IP address,

72
00:03:30.413 --> 00:03:31.976
everything's working good there.

73
00:03:31.976 --> 00:03:34.620
I wanna talk a little
bit more about scopes.

74
00:03:34.620 --> 00:03:37.740
And we're gonna talk about superscopes and
multicast scopes.

75
00:03:37.740 --> 00:03:42.186
We'll come back around and talk about some
of these options here in just a second.

76
00:03:42.186 --> 00:03:49.268
But our scope, in our case has a pool of,
I forgot how many we set up, 189, 188.

77
00:03:49.268 --> 00:03:53.299
188 addresses, somewhere around there.

78
00:03:53.299 --> 00:03:54.950
We can do something called a superscope.

79
00:03:54.950 --> 00:03:58.992
And a superscope is nothing more
than a combination of scopes,

80
00:03:58.992 --> 00:04:02.440
more than one scope
kinda plugged together.

81
00:04:02.440 --> 00:04:06.008
You don't see these that often,
but they're still there and

82
00:04:06.008 --> 00:04:08.110
we should know what they are.

83
00:04:08.110 --> 00:04:10.290
And again, it's a combination of scopes.

84
00:04:10.290 --> 00:04:13.750
And you see this in places where they're
going through some growing pains.

85
00:04:13.750 --> 00:04:16.760
They started out with
a class C network address.

86
00:04:16.760 --> 00:04:20.775
So you got 254 possible hosts minus
any exclusions that you made and

87
00:04:20.775 --> 00:04:21.873
things like that.

88
00:04:21.873 --> 00:04:25.990
And yeah, we've only got 50 hosts,
that'll last us forever.

89
00:04:25.990 --> 00:04:29.070
Until you start figuring out that
everybody brings in their laptop,

90
00:04:29.070 --> 00:04:33.940
and their tablet, and their phone, and
their watch, and their tennis shoes.

91
00:04:33.940 --> 00:04:38.000
And they all wanna connect to the [LAUGH]
wireless access to your network.

92
00:04:38.000 --> 00:04:40.920
So they're just eating up your addresses
faster than you can dish them out.

93
00:04:40.920 --> 00:04:44.220
And pretty soon you're like,
no, I'm out of addresses.

94
00:04:44.220 --> 00:04:48.510
And if you lease all those addresses out,
and then somebody else says, hey,

95
00:04:48.510 --> 00:04:51.490
I need an IP address,
your DHCP server can't do anything.

96
00:04:51.490 --> 00:04:53.830
He just says, sorry, I'm out of addresses.

97
00:04:53.830 --> 00:04:56.720
If somebody gives one up,
I'll give you that one, but until then,

98
00:04:56.720 --> 00:04:59.136
you're kinda up the creek without
the paddle, if you know what I mean.

99
00:04:59.136 --> 00:05:03.280
So maybe where we're going
through those growing pains,

100
00:05:03.280 --> 00:05:07.440
what I can do is I can create
another class C scope, okay.

101
00:05:07.440 --> 00:05:11.930
And then I can merge the, not really
merge the two, but I can join the two and

102
00:05:11.930 --> 00:05:13.510
treat them as a unit.

103
00:05:13.510 --> 00:05:18.350
And I can basically double up or
gain more IP addresses.

104
00:05:18.350 --> 00:05:22.086
For example, let me go ahead and
create a couple just test scopes so

105
00:05:22.086 --> 00:05:23.634
I don't goof up our scope.

106
00:05:23.634 --> 00:05:27.475
I'm gonna create a new scope,
and I'm gonna do this real quick.

107
00:05:27.475 --> 00:05:30.187
I'm just gonna call this test1.

108
00:05:30.187 --> 00:05:34.499
And I'll say, we're gonna give

109
00:05:34.499 --> 00:05:39.431
out 192.168.1.1 through

110
00:05:39.431 --> 00:05:44.650
192.168.1.254.

111
00:05:44.650 --> 00:05:47.606
And that's not 254, Mike, there we go.

112
00:05:47.606 --> 00:05:50.130
And I'll click Next, no exclusions.

113
00:05:50.130 --> 00:05:52.370
Next, Next, Next, just again,
all the defaults.

114
00:05:52.370 --> 00:05:55.560
I'm not even gonna configure the options,
and Finish.

115
00:05:55.560 --> 00:05:59.921
And then I'm gonna make another one
real quick and do Scope > Next,

116
00:05:59.921 --> 00:06:04.448
call this one, you'll never guess,
oops, evidently it won't go-

117
00:06:04.448 --> 00:06:05.108
>> No, they won't.

118
00:06:05.108 --> 00:06:06.333
>> I'll call it ET, yeah.

119
00:06:06.333 --> 00:06:10.724
>> [LAUGH]
>> Test2, we'll go Next, and

120
00:06:10.724 --> 00:06:16.106
this one's gonna be 192.168.2.1

121
00:06:16.106 --> 00:06:20.940
through 192.168.2.254.

122
00:06:20.940 --> 00:06:27.380
Same thing, Next, no exclusions, nothing,
configure those later, Next > Finish.

123
00:06:27.380 --> 00:06:28.950
So now I've got these two scopes.

124
00:06:28.950 --> 00:06:31.390
And that's an important thing to note,

125
00:06:31.390 --> 00:06:34.170
that I made the two scopes
before I made the superscope.

126
00:06:34.170 --> 00:06:37.240
Cuz what you're gonna see is when I
go through the superscope wizard,

127
00:06:37.240 --> 00:06:39.720
there is no create scope option.

128
00:06:39.720 --> 00:06:42.240
You're gonna pick from existing scopes.

129
00:06:42.240 --> 00:06:44.320
So the scopes have to
be made ahead of time,

130
00:06:44.320 --> 00:06:46.270
then you can combine
them into a superscope.

131
00:06:46.270 --> 00:06:48.950
I'm gonna right-click, New Superscope.

132
00:06:48.950 --> 00:06:51.900
I just like saying that, superscope.

133
00:06:51.900 --> 00:06:54.550
It's the new and improved mouthwash!

134
00:06:54.550 --> 00:06:59.700
I'll click Next, and I'm gonna give
the scope name of a Supertest,

135
00:06:59.700 --> 00:07:02.740
and we'll click Next.

136
00:07:02.740 --> 00:07:07.450
And here you can see my list of available
subnets, I'll choose the two that I want.

137
00:07:08.580 --> 00:07:11.540
I'll click Next > Finish, and that's it.

138
00:07:11.540 --> 00:07:16.100
Notice they're gone individually,
they're now hidden underneath superscope.

139
00:07:16.100 --> 00:07:20.670
They're still there, they're just
underneath my superscope, all right.

140
00:07:20.670 --> 00:07:22.530
And that's how you can increase.

141
00:07:22.530 --> 00:07:26.650
So if you're planning on growing the
network, but you're not ready to redo your

142
00:07:26.650 --> 00:07:31.080
entire structure, you could just make
another subnet or another scope.

143
00:07:31.080 --> 00:07:34.220
Kinda join it with a different scope and

144
00:07:34.220 --> 00:07:37.680
basically add addresses
to your possible pool.

145
00:07:37.680 --> 00:07:42.394
Do keep in mind, though, that technically,
if I get an address from this network and

146
00:07:42.394 --> 00:07:45.012
another guy gets an address
from this network,

147
00:07:45.012 --> 00:07:47.384
they're not on the same network, right?

148
00:07:47.384 --> 00:07:53.391
That was a class C, that's a 255,
it's a 192.168.1.network and a 2.network.

149
00:07:53.391 --> 00:07:55.490
So you are gonna have to
deal with routing and

150
00:07:55.490 --> 00:07:58.121
making sure that everything
is configured properly.

151
00:07:58.121 --> 00:08:00.504
To support both of those ranges.

152
00:08:00.504 --> 00:08:03.353
Cuz if Wes' client,
if he reboots his machine,

153
00:08:03.353 --> 00:08:07.250
he gets an IP address
from 192.168.1 today.

154
00:08:07.250 --> 00:08:11.042
Next week when his lease expires,
he might get one from 192.168.2.0.

155
00:08:11.042 --> 00:08:13.019
Which means he needs a different gateway.

156
00:08:13.019 --> 00:08:15.360
And there has be to routing setup for
that.

157
00:08:15.360 --> 00:08:17.010
So do keep that in mind.

158
00:08:17.010 --> 00:08:18.352
That's a superscope.

159
00:08:18.352 --> 00:08:21.740
You can also create
a multicast scope in DNS.

160
00:08:21.740 --> 00:08:24.998
I can right, DNS, DHCP.

161
00:08:24.998 --> 00:08:27.667
I can right-click New multicast Scope.

162
00:08:27.667 --> 00:08:29.800
And it's gonna run me through a wizard,
as well.

163
00:08:29.800 --> 00:08:33.260
Multicast, hopefully, again,
if you've been through your Network+,

164
00:08:33.260 --> 00:08:36.195
you've familiar with
the concept of a multicast.

165
00:08:36.195 --> 00:08:38.260
We got different types of casts.

166
00:08:38.260 --> 00:08:42.080
We got sidearm casts,
we got the overhead, no.

167
00:08:42.080 --> 00:08:46.005
You got one-to-one,
one-to-all, and one-to-many.

168
00:08:46.005 --> 00:08:52.360
One-to-one, unicast, one-to-all,
broadcast, one-to-many is your multicast.

169
00:08:52.360 --> 00:08:54.800
Not everybody, but more than one, usually.

170
00:08:54.800 --> 00:09:00.360
You do that for like video conferences
a lot of times, what we're doing here.

171
00:09:00.360 --> 00:09:03.650
This is a one, Wes and
I are the one, to many.

172
00:09:03.650 --> 00:09:05.370
I have many viewers out
there watching this.

173
00:09:05.370 --> 00:09:07.570
So I got one stream going out, but

174
00:09:07.570 --> 00:09:10.720
it's actually being delivered
to many destinations.

175
00:09:10.720 --> 00:09:14.764
Kind of in a way, that would
represent a multicast, all right?

176
00:09:14.764 --> 00:09:15.552
Now technically,

177
00:09:15.552 --> 00:09:19.130
I understand that that's not really
the way it's working in the background.

178
00:09:19.130 --> 00:09:23.480
But the concept is the same, all right?

179
00:09:23.480 --> 00:09:24.990
You give it a name.

180
00:09:24.990 --> 00:09:30.940
I can just call this MultiTest, all right.

181
00:09:30.940 --> 00:09:36.188
And remember, your multicast range, 224
through 239, anything, anything, anything.

182
00:09:36.188 --> 00:09:40.974
So say 224.1.1.1 through

183
00:09:40.974 --> 00:09:47.998
224.1.1.254, and we'll click Next.

184
00:09:47.998 --> 00:09:49.700
No exclusions.

185
00:09:49.700 --> 00:09:54.010
We'll give it a 30-day lease, Next,
and I'm not gonna activate it.

186
00:09:54.010 --> 00:09:56.370
I don't want it getting in our way
while we're doing the rest of our labs.

187
00:09:56.370 --> 00:09:57.330
And Finish.
