00:21:53.180 --> 00:21:57.450
Let's do something different, but it does
have to be from within the scope and

417
00:21:57.450 --> 00:21:59.336
not one of my excluded addresses.

418
00:21:59.336 --> 00:22:03.864
So let's do 10.0.100.47.

419
00:22:03.864 --> 00:22:06.640
That'll be an odd one we'll know
that the reservation worked and

420
00:22:06.640 --> 00:22:07.858
then the MAC address, Wes?

421
00:22:07.858 --> 00:22:11.950
>> That's gonna be 00155D0AD206.

422
00:22:18.500 --> 00:22:19.760
>> There we go.

423
00:22:19.760 --> 00:22:24.320
And I'll skip the description and I'll
go ahead and click Add and then Close.

424
00:22:24.320 --> 00:22:28.880
Now if I go to look at reservations,
there's my reservation.

425
00:22:28.880 --> 00:22:32.020
Notice it's picking up all the scope level
options because it is still part of this

426
00:22:32.020 --> 00:22:33.440
scope, right.

427
00:22:34.650 --> 00:22:36.260
And let's see what happens.

428
00:22:36.260 --> 00:22:38.729
We're going to switch
back over to the client.

429
00:22:41.140 --> 00:22:44.340
So back to vmhost where I've
got my remote desktop for

430
00:22:44.340 --> 00:22:47.260
that client, I should say my
virtual machine connection,

431
00:22:47.260 --> 00:22:49.280
that way I do not have to worry
about IP addresses changing.

432
00:22:49.280 --> 00:22:51.690
I am on the vmhost right now

433
00:22:51.690 --> 00:22:54.740
connected to this guy Which makes
it a little more convenient.

434
00:22:54.740 --> 00:22:56.230
So Wes how do I give up?

435
00:22:56.230 --> 00:22:58.930
I've got a lease currently
I want to throw it away?

436
00:22:58.930 --> 00:23:00.830
>> Man I tell you,
you're rally challenging me today.

437
00:23:00.830 --> 00:23:02.870
>> [LAUGH]
>> I want to say this one is forward

438
00:23:02.870 --> 00:23:04.800
ip config since you're
gonna give me half of it.

439
00:23:04.800 --> 00:23:07.290
Space forward slash release.

440
00:23:08.360 --> 00:23:12.450
>> Release all right, oops and
you do have to spell it right don't you?

441
00:23:12.450 --> 00:23:13.965
>> You've been looking at my type.

442
00:23:13.965 --> 00:23:18.368
>> [LAUGH] There,
that looks more like release.

443
00:23:18.368 --> 00:23:19.281
All right.

444
00:23:19.281 --> 00:23:21.380
[LAUGH] I just felt the first one.

445
00:23:21.380 --> 00:23:25.414
Let me just start all over,
ipconfig/release.

446
00:23:25.414 --> 00:23:27.310
All right.

447
00:23:27.310 --> 00:23:30.960
And then of course I forgot to
run an administrative prompt.

448
00:23:30.960 --> 00:23:31.920
So let's do that.

449
00:23:31.920 --> 00:23:34.850
Let's right click,
run as an administrator.

450
00:23:36.110 --> 00:23:42.038
Yes to the UAC,
third time is always the charm

451
00:23:42.038 --> 00:23:47.505
IP config switch release and there we go.

452
00:23:47.505 --> 00:23:50.904
Notice I've got no IP
addresses down here for

453
00:23:50.904 --> 00:23:53.863
ethernet adapter and then I can do the.

454
00:23:55.223 --> 00:23:58.560
I forget the word I'm looking for, but-
>> Give it back.

455
00:23:58.560 --> 00:23:59.672
>> Yeah, I wanna get the IP address back.

456
00:23:59.672 --> 00:24:00.529
>> [LAUGH] Renew.

457
00:24:00.529 --> 00:24:03.090
>> The command that goes along with it,
not the symbiotic partner.

458
00:24:03.090 --> 00:24:06.970
I was trying to get the term I wanted to
use there, but my brain has failed me.

459
00:24:06.970 --> 00:24:09.250
Ipconfig renew says hey,
go get a new lease.

460
00:24:09.250 --> 00:24:11.990
Release says,
throw away your current lease.

461
00:24:11.990 --> 00:24:14.738
Renew says, go get a new lease.

462
00:24:14.738 --> 00:24:15.530
So we'll try it out.

463
00:24:17.010 --> 00:24:19.540
Ethernet two is unplugged,
that's why it says that for that guy.

464
00:24:21.210 --> 00:24:22.720
We'll wait for it.

465
00:24:22.720 --> 00:24:24.730
>> And while we're waiting,
I've also seen, it's kinda interesting.

466
00:24:24.730 --> 00:24:28.038
Cuz Bluetooth doesn't do that,
it doesn't do the whole DORA process.

467
00:24:28.038 --> 00:24:31.200
But if you've got Bluetooth
network adaptors it says,

468
00:24:31.200 --> 00:24:34.170
this can't be performed
on the Bluetooth adapter.

469
00:24:34.170 --> 00:24:34.990
Well, thank you anyway.

470
00:24:34.990 --> 00:24:36.147
>> Cuz they're too good for it.

471
00:24:36.147 --> 00:24:37.964
>> [LAUGH]
>> And there we go,

472
00:24:37.964 --> 00:24:41.670
I got my IP address back and
look what IP address I got.

473
00:24:41.670 --> 00:24:46.290
And if I release and renew it 100 times,
I would always get that same IP address.

474
00:24:46.290 --> 00:24:47.920
The other information might change.

475
00:24:47.920 --> 00:24:51.910
I might go into my options and
change the DNS suffix, or

476
00:24:51.910 --> 00:24:56.200
the default gateway, or I might decide
to start passing out a WINS address.

477
00:24:56.200 --> 00:24:57.770
I don't have to do
anything to this client.

478
00:24:57.770 --> 00:25:02.436
The next time it renews its lease,
it'll pick up that new information

479
00:25:02.436 --> 00:25:07.119
automatically, yet still get the same
IP address every single time.

480
00:25:07.119 --> 00:25:11.120
So reservations are great,
a little manual on the set-up, but

481
00:25:11.120 --> 00:25:15.920
once you get that set up,
you don't have to do anything else, right?

482
00:25:15.920 --> 00:25:18.061
So we just create that reservation for
that client.

483
00:25:18.061 --> 00:25:22.150
And of course I can create as
many reservations as I want.

484
00:25:22.150 --> 00:25:25.321
All right, last thing I wanna talk
about in this particular episode.

485
00:25:25.321 --> 00:25:26.559
We talked about the options.

486
00:25:26.559 --> 00:25:30.723
There are scope-level options,
there are server-level options, and

487
00:25:30.723 --> 00:25:32.600
we can change them at anytime.

488
00:25:32.600 --> 00:25:36.800
I mean, I can go back into the options and
I could pull up this particular one and

489
00:25:36.800 --> 00:25:41.190
remove that, or I could add another one.

490
00:25:41.190 --> 00:25:42.270
Let me add that back.

491
00:25:42.270 --> 00:25:47.765
And I can say,
I also wanna pass out 10.0.100.201.

492
00:25:47.765 --> 00:25:51.151
That's another one of my DNS servers,
cuz we wanna pass out more than one.

493
00:25:51.151 --> 00:25:55.450
That way if one's not responding,
the other one can help the client out.

494
00:25:55.450 --> 00:25:57.770
So I can go back and
modify these options at any time.

495
00:25:59.210 --> 00:26:03.830
And it's gonna try to validate that
there's not really a DNS server there.

496
00:26:03.830 --> 00:26:04.810
It's trying to validate it.

497
00:26:04.810 --> 00:26:06.560
I'm gonna say yes, add it anyway.

498
00:26:06.560 --> 00:26:08.100
Trying to protect me from myself.

499
00:26:08.100 --> 00:26:11.102
Thank you Windows, but
this is just a demonstration.

500
00:26:11.102 --> 00:26:11.683
Go ahead.

501
00:26:11.683 --> 00:26:12.926
[LAUGH]
>> I was just gonna ask,

502
00:26:12.926 --> 00:26:15.190
do you have to restart the DHCP service?

503
00:26:15.190 --> 00:26:18.640
Or is it smart enough to know that hey,
I'll do this in the background for

504
00:26:18.640 --> 00:26:21.000
you when you add that additional option?

505
00:26:21.000 --> 00:26:21.980
>> Yep, it'll just take care of it.

506
00:26:21.980 --> 00:26:23.297
You don't have to restart anything.

507
00:26:24.758 --> 00:26:26.429
And what else was I gonna say?

508
00:26:26.429 --> 00:26:28.022
And then the subnet itself, right?

509
00:26:28.022 --> 00:26:29.293
I can go over here to the subnet.

510
00:26:29.293 --> 00:26:35.642
What if I wanted to change my pool or
my exclusions?

511
00:26:35.642 --> 00:26:39.767
I just realized that Wes statically mapped
a printer that was in the middle of

512
00:26:39.767 --> 00:26:40.289
my pool.

513
00:26:40.289 --> 00:26:45.380
10.0.100.14 is actually one
of our network printers.

514
00:26:45.380 --> 00:26:49.076
Well, I can simply come back
over here to this scope, and

515
00:26:49.076 --> 00:26:51.698
I can go to the properties of this scope.

516
00:26:51.698 --> 00:26:55.194
And I'm sorry,
not the properties of the scope, silly me.

517
00:26:55.194 --> 00:26:59.127
I can go to my exclusions over here,
Address Pool, and

518
00:26:59.127 --> 00:27:01.640
New Exclusion Range, right?

519
00:27:01.640 --> 00:27:03.690
And I could add that address in there.

520
00:27:03.690 --> 00:27:08.090
But there is one thing, and
this is really the point of all this.

521
00:27:08.090 --> 00:27:15.140
You can change everything about the scope,
except for one very important thing.

522
00:27:15.140 --> 00:27:19.320
I'm gonna right-click on this scope again,
and I'm gonna choose Properties.

523
00:27:19.320 --> 00:27:22.090
And there was a change
the name of the scope.

524
00:27:22.090 --> 00:27:24.180
I could change the start and
end IP address.

525
00:27:24.180 --> 00:27:26.390
I can change the lease duration.

526
00:27:26.390 --> 00:27:30.050
I can change how DNS is
playing along with DHCP,

527
00:27:30.050 --> 00:27:32.080
which we're gonna talk
about in another episode.

528
00:27:32.080 --> 00:27:35.090
I've got some advanced
options that I can change.

529
00:27:35.090 --> 00:27:38.050
There's one thing on this tab though,
Wes, that I cannot change.

530
00:27:38.050 --> 00:27:38.670
Can you spot it?

531
00:27:38.670 --> 00:27:42.160
>> It looks like you're gonna be set
with the same subnet mask length.

532
00:27:42.160 --> 00:27:44.530
>> Notice how that is greyed out?

533
00:27:44.530 --> 00:27:46.051
You cannot change it.

534
00:27:46.051 --> 00:27:51.150
And this would make a very
good test question.

535
00:27:51.150 --> 00:27:54.150
You have created,
your co-workers created a scope,

536
00:27:54.150 --> 00:27:56.720
but they ended up using
the wrong subnet mask.

537
00:27:56.720 --> 00:27:58.020
You need to change it.

538
00:27:58.020 --> 00:28:01.350
How do you go about updating
the subnet mask on an existing scope?

539
00:28:01.350 --> 00:28:01.940
What's the answer, Wes?

540
00:28:01.940 --> 00:28:04.490
>> My guess is you're gonna have
to delete it and recreate it.

541
00:28:04.490 --> 00:28:07.200
>> And you would be correct,
gold star for you today.

542
00:28:07.200 --> 00:28:09.420
That's the only way to fix that.

543
00:28:09.420 --> 00:28:11.230
The only thing you can't change, or

544
00:28:11.230 --> 00:28:13.660
the biggest thing you can't change,
is the subnet mask.

545
00:28:13.660 --> 00:28:15.240
The only way to change it?

546
00:28:15.240 --> 00:28:17.790
There's no magic PowerShell command,
nothing.

547
00:28:17.790 --> 00:28:22.145
You delete the scope, and you recreate
the scope with the correct subnet mask,

548
00:28:22.145 --> 00:28:23.090
all right?

549
00:28:23.090 --> 00:28:26.780
So just a little gotcha,
that in the real world, can throw you off,

550
00:28:26.780 --> 00:28:27.930
how come I can't change this?

551
00:28:27.930 --> 00:28:29.080
What's going on?

552
00:28:29.080 --> 00:28:33.800
On the exam it'd be a really easy one to
miss, or if you didn't know what it was,

553
00:28:33.800 --> 00:28:35.800
you're like,
I don't understand the question.

554
00:28:35.800 --> 00:28:38.218
So do understand, and of course
they won't ask you that question.

555
00:28:38.218 --> 00:28:41.010
I can't talk about
the actual questions anyway.

556
00:28:41.010 --> 00:28:44.979
And if I said one of the questions,
you would never get that one.

557
00:28:44.979 --> 00:28:48.306
That's just the way Murphy's law works,
right?

558
00:28:48.306 --> 00:28:51.640
But yeah, just keep in mind,
you can't change that subnet mask anyway.

559
00:28:51.640 --> 00:28:54.462
Way back in the day when I first
started studying, it drove me crazy.

560
00:28:54.462 --> 00:28:56.820
I was like wait, what's wrong,
why is this grayed out?

561
00:28:56.820 --> 00:28:59.397
I typed in the wrong address or
the wrong subnet mask, and

562
00:28:59.397 --> 00:29:00.802
it wouldn't let me change it.

563
00:29:00.802 --> 00:29:01.963
You can't, so, [LAUGH].

564
00:29:01.963 --> 00:29:04.629
>> Well that's a lot of
great information on DHCP.

565
00:29:04.629 --> 00:29:08.150
And this again, is such a complex topic
and a lot of great information, Mike.

566
00:29:08.150 --> 00:29:11.290
Now I know we're coming to
the end of another episode.

567
00:29:11.290 --> 00:29:15.310
Do you got any, in this one, any advice
you would like to maybe give about DNS

568
00:29:15.310 --> 00:29:19.470
options or the reservations that you
might want somebody to keep in mind?

569
00:29:19.470 --> 00:29:22.447
>> Just think about the scope and
the server-level options,

570
00:29:22.447 --> 00:29:23.822
do pay attention to those.

571
00:29:23.822 --> 00:29:27.109
Again, server-level options are passed out
to everybody that talks to that server,

572
00:29:27.109 --> 00:29:29.350
no matter what scope you're coming from.

573
00:29:29.350 --> 00:29:30.507
One more thing that I didn't mention.

574
00:29:30.507 --> 00:29:33.740
Thank you for letting me do this, cuz it
prompted me to think of something else.

575
00:29:33.740 --> 00:29:35.590
What if there's a server-level option and

576
00:29:35.590 --> 00:29:38.570
a scope-level option that
are configuring the same thing, right?

577
00:29:38.570 --> 00:29:41.181
Because I can set a server-level option,
for say,

578
00:29:41.181 --> 00:29:43.448
the DNS server address
that I wanna pass out.

579
00:29:43.448 --> 00:29:47.450
But I can also go to the scope and I could
set a scope-level option that passes out

580
00:29:47.450 --> 00:29:50.970
a DNS server address, and
it might be a different DNS server.

581
00:29:50.970 --> 00:29:52.640
What happens then, right?

582
00:29:52.640 --> 00:29:58.150
It actually applies them from
least specific to most specific.

583
00:29:58.150 --> 00:30:00.390
So your server-level
option gets applied first.

584
00:30:00.390 --> 00:30:04.330
But then your scope-level option
can override any server-level

585
00:30:04.330 --> 00:30:05.940
options that it conflicts with.

586
00:30:05.940 --> 00:30:09.630
So you might have 20 scopes,
and you wanna set all 20,

587
00:30:09.630 --> 00:30:13.080
all 19 of them, to the same DNS server.

588
00:30:13.080 --> 00:30:16.322
One of them needs a different DNS server,
the one that the executives use.

589
00:30:16.322 --> 00:30:19.778
And you wanna make sure they get good
performance, cuz they sign your paychecks.

590
00:30:19.778 --> 00:30:22.730
So what you'd do is you'd set
a server-level option for

591
00:30:22.730 --> 00:30:25.770
the common DNS server
that us common folk use.

592
00:30:25.770 --> 00:30:28.590
And that would actually
apply to all 20 scopes.

593
00:30:28.590 --> 00:30:30.630
But then you'd go to that one scope and

594
00:30:30.630 --> 00:30:35.140
set the DNS server option there at
the scope-level for the executive scope.

595
00:30:35.140 --> 00:30:38.639
That would override the sever-level
option, but just for that one scope.

596
00:30:38.639 --> 00:30:40.596
They'd have their own
private DNS server and

597
00:30:40.596 --> 00:30:43.082
wouldn't have to deal with
traffic from us common folk.

598
00:30:43.082 --> 00:30:47.850
So understand that scope-level options
will override server-level options.

599
00:30:47.850 --> 00:30:50.443
If we were to talk about,
they don't call it out anymore, but

600
00:30:50.443 --> 00:30:54.660
vendor class and user class options
are actually more specific than scope.

601
00:30:54.660 --> 00:30:56.730
So those would override
scope-level options.

602
00:30:56.730 --> 00:30:59.040
You can also do reservation-level options.

603
00:30:59.040 --> 00:31:02.280
You can do an option at
the reservation level.

604
00:31:02.280 --> 00:31:06.650
It's not used very often, that's why they
don't talk about it much anymore I guess,

605
00:31:06.650 --> 00:31:09.180
because it's really an option for one.

606
00:31:09.180 --> 00:31:11.000
It's not very efficient, all right?

607
00:31:11.000 --> 00:31:13.757
It's not too often that I have
an option for just one machine.

608
00:31:13.757 --> 00:31:16.687
But understand you can set
an option at the reservation level,

609
00:31:16.687 --> 00:31:18.021
which is the most specific.

610
00:31:18.021 --> 00:31:22.750
So that would override user and
vendor class options, scope options and

611
00:31:22.750 --> 00:31:24.730
server options.

612
00:31:24.730 --> 00:31:26.100
And that's what I'll leave you with.

613
00:31:26.100 --> 00:31:28.710
>> All right, well that's
a great place to sign off here.

614
00:31:28.710 --> 00:31:31.260
For ITPRO.TV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

615
00:31:31.260 --> 00:31:32.020
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

616
00:31:32.020 --> 00:31:33.263
>> And we'll see you next time.

617
00:31:33.263 --> 00:31:40.573
[MUSIC]

618
00:31:40.573 --> 00:31:42.435
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

2016.

>> Doing fantastic.

16
00:00:33.763 --> 00:00:34.457
Thanks for having me back.

17
00:00:34.457 --> 00:00:40.402
And yeah, continuing on with good old
DHCP, Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol.

18
00:00:40.402 --> 00:00:44.986
In this episode,
we're gonna focus in on of the new

19
00:00:44.986 --> 00:00:50.327
capabilities of the DHCP, and
that's gonna be policies.

20
00:00:50.327 --> 00:00:55.829
We've seen already how to get it
installed, how to configure these options.

21
00:00:55.829 --> 00:00:58.427
And while DHCP itself is
very dynamic in other words,

22
00:00:58.427 --> 00:01:01.903
it can pass this information from
the client's perspective, right?

23
00:01:01.903 --> 00:01:02.519
It's dynamic.

24
00:01:02.519 --> 00:01:05.072
Because I don't have to
statically map the client.

25
00:01:05.072 --> 00:01:08.888
They get an IP address automatically,
that can change.

26
00:01:08.888 --> 00:01:13.690
But the options that we've configured
are relatively static, right?

27
00:01:13.690 --> 00:01:15.871
I say relatively,
they pretty much are static.

28
00:01:15.871 --> 00:01:20.638
They apply to either everybody on
the server or everybody in that scope.

29
00:01:20.638 --> 00:01:24.340
We do have the ability to do it at
the reservation level for individual node.

clients based on their IP address,
or their MAC address, or

255
00:15:02.360 --> 00:15:06.182
their names, their FQDN or
client identifier.

256
00:15:06.182 --> 00:15:08.801
So really cool things that they've added,

257
00:15:08.801 --> 00:15:13.200
giving us a little more flexibility and
control within our DHCP surface.

258
00:15:14.840 --> 00:15:16.090
>> And that's really cool, Mike.

259
00:15:16.090 --> 00:15:19.524
Cuz like you've mentioned that DHCP,
if I got a client on the network and

260
00:15:19.524 --> 00:15:23.380
it just calls out, I mean DHCP is
configured, hey, here's the address.

261
00:15:23.380 --> 00:15:26.509
And now being able to add
a condition like and or or, and

262
00:15:26.509 --> 00:15:28.766
then an operator equal to or less than.

263
00:15:28.766 --> 00:15:32.022
And here's what I'm really impressed
about is the fact that you didn't change

264
00:15:32.022 --> 00:15:33.292
the underlying DHCP service.

265
00:15:33.292 --> 00:15:35.046
You didn't have to reinvent the wheel.

266
00:15:35.046 --> 00:15:37.524
Now it does look like we're coming
to the end of another episode.

267
00:15:37.524 --> 00:15:40.831
But before we do, Mike, do you got any
additional maybe words of wisdom for

268
00:15:40.831 --> 00:15:41.364
policies?

269
00:15:41.364 --> 00:15:43.622
>> I can't think of any
off the top of my head.

270
00:15:43.622 --> 00:15:45.350
Play around with them, do test them.

271
00:15:45.350 --> 00:15:47.690
Make sure that you're getting
the results that you expect.

272
00:15:47.690 --> 00:15:51.415
Make sure that it's identifying
those nodes correctly.

273
00:15:51.415 --> 00:15:53.543
Like you saw with the wild cards there,

274
00:15:53.543 --> 00:15:56.200
it's not as straight forward
as I like to see it.

275
00:15:56.200 --> 00:16:01.940
I can't do asterisk lab asterisk, I got
to do asterisk lab and then lab asterisk.

276
00:16:01.940 --> 00:16:05.876
And that might not work if lab
is in the middle of the name so.

277
00:16:05.876 --> 00:16:08.508
But maybe you can figure something else
that all machines start with this.

278
00:16:08.508 --> 00:16:12.395
So again it just comes down to kind of
exploring your options there with those

279
00:16:12.395 --> 00:16:13.660
polices.

280
00:16:13.660 --> 00:16:14.856
>> Mike, a lot of great information.

281
00:16:14.856 --> 00:16:17.656
It looks like that's a great
place to sign off for ITPro.TV.

282
00:16:17.656 --> 00:16:19.592
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

283
00:16:19.592 --> 00:16:20.728
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

284
00:16:20.728 --> 00:16:22.552
>> And we'll see you next time.

285

[MUSIC]

286
00:16:29.542 --> 00:16:31.885
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

7

12

thanks for having me back.

13

>> You're welcome.
>> And you're right,

14
00:00:35.005 --> 00:00:38.263
continuing on with good old DHCP,
we got some cool things we wanna look at.

15
00:00:38.263 --> 00:00:41.919
Something to take you to that
next level with good old DHCP.

16
00:00:41.919 --> 00:00:44.441
We saw some of the basics,
in the previous episode.

17
00:00:44.441 --> 00:00:45.709
We got it installed,

18
00:00:45.709 --> 00:00:49.940
we created some scopes, talked
a little bit about that process there.

19
00:00:49.940 --> 00:00:52.426
And the first thing we're
gonna look at today,

20
00:00:52.426 --> 00:00:54.830
is something known as a relay agent.

21
00:00:54.830 --> 00:00:57.850
>> All right, so Mike,
in terms of this idea of the relay agent.

22
00:00:59.510 --> 00:01:00.420
I understand something,

23
00:01:00.420 --> 00:01:04.680
that when we actually set up a DHCP
server, I need to have a DHCP server.

24
00:01:04.680 --> 00:01:07.820
But there's a way for me,
to actually have a single DHCP server.

25
00:01:07.820 --> 00:01:10.310
But they can actually even
serve out IP addresses,

26
00:01:10.310 --> 00:01:12.350
for multiple subnets as well, right?

27
00:01:12.350 --> 00:01:16.030
>> Exactly right,
we're gonna be able to manage or

28
00:01:16.030 --> 00:01:19.230
provide IP addresses with a single server,
to multiple subnets.

29
00:01:19.230 --> 00:01:23.210
Now, one of the things we have to
think about is that DHCP process.

30
00:01:23.210 --> 00:01:26.664
We didn't really go into
the details of DORA,

31
00:01:26.664 --> 00:01:30.660
D-O-R-A, Discover Offer
Request Acknowledge.

32
00:01:30.660 --> 00:01:33.637
But, when we talk about DHCP,
what we have to remember,

33
00:01:33.637 --> 00:01:36.181
is that all of those that
initial conversation,

34
00:01:36.181 --> 00:01:40.170
that conversation between the client,
that's looking for an IP address.

35
00:01:40.170 --> 00:01:43.512
And the DHCP server that's
providing the IP address,

36
00:01:43.512 --> 00:01:46.710
all of that is done using broadcast.

37
00:01:46.710 --> 00:01:50.460
When we talk about unicast, versus
multicast versus broadcast, and Ronnie,

38
00:01:50.460 --> 00:01:51.870
you're our Cisco guy.

39
00:01:51.870 --> 00:01:53.430
By default, if I don't configure it,

40
00:01:53.430 --> 00:01:56.550
what do routers typically
do with broadcast traffic?

41
00:01:56.550 --> 00:01:58.800
>> When you start taking
a look at the idea of routers,

42
00:01:58.800 --> 00:02:02.360
routers normally by default do
not allow broadcast traffic,

43
00:02:02.360 --> 00:02:04.930
to pass from one interface
to another interface.

44
00:02:04.930 --> 00:02:06.520
So it effectively blocks it.

45
00:02:06.520 --> 00:02:10.490
Now we can actually make it change and
do some other things with it, but

46
00:02:10.490 --> 00:02:13.750
overall though, by its default,
it actually stops it.

47
00:02:13.750 --> 00:02:15.620
So the reason why that's
important Mike for

48
00:02:15.620 --> 00:02:20.670
DHCP, is that that means if I have
another IP address that I need to hand

49
00:02:20.670 --> 00:02:24.700
out in a different subnet, I can't get it
through, so how is this gonna work, Mike?

50
00:02:24.700 --> 00:02:27.470
>> Exactly, that's what Relay Agent,
is gonna do for us.

51
00:02:27.470 --> 00:02:29.618
It's gonna help us out in this scenario.

52
00:02:29.618 --> 00:02:32.092
So let's take a look, and
I have got it set up.

53
00:02:32.092 --> 00:02:33.515
We're gonna start off very simple.

54
00:02:33.515 --> 00:02:36.340
I've got my domain controller,
that we're using the other day.

55
00:02:36.340 --> 00:02:38.438
If I open up the DHCP console.

56
00:02:39.955 --> 00:02:44.297
We have our DHCP server still
configured and if we take a look,

57
00:02:44.297 --> 00:02:47.720
I've got a couple of
scopes that I created.

58
00:02:47.720 --> 00:02:50.990
We got the 1000 subnet here.

59
00:02:50.990 --> 00:02:53.000
And let's take a look at what we've got.

60
00:02:53.000 --> 00:02:54.170
Let's flip over to the client.

61
00:02:55.660 --> 00:03:01.620
I'm doing all of this via Virtual Machine
connection, rather than remote desktop.

62
00:03:01.620 --> 00:03:03.770
Cuz we're gonna be changing IP addresses,
and

63
00:03:03.770 --> 00:03:05.550
it makes it very difficult
to remote into the guy.

64
00:03:05.550 --> 00:03:09.340
So bear with me as I switch back and
forth, between these machines.

65
00:03:09.340 --> 00:03:12.920
We flip over to my client, and
we open up little PowerShell,

66
00:03:12.920 --> 00:03:15.920
and we do a little ipconfig, switch all.

67
00:03:17.080 --> 00:03:21.300
I can see that I've got an address,
but that is statically mapped.

68
00:03:21.300 --> 00:03:23.110
DHCP enabled, no.

69
00:03:23.110 --> 00:03:24.500
So let's change that.

70
00:03:24.500 --> 00:03:28.470
Let's get our client,
to get an IP Address from the DHCP server.

71
00:03:28.470 --> 00:03:30.369
So I'm gonna pull up my
Network Adapter settings.

72
00:03:32.103 --> 00:03:35.593
And we'll go in and
we'll change that to a DHCP client,

73
00:03:35.593 --> 00:03:38.872
by pulling up the Properties
on my Network Adapter.

74
00:03:38.872 --> 00:03:42.193
Diving into IPv4 and
telling it to obtain an IP address, and

75
00:03:42.193 --> 00:03:44.870
a DNS server address automatically.

76
00:03:44.870 --> 00:03:49.520
I'll click OK a couple of times,
we'll let that kick in And hopefully,

77
00:03:49.520 --> 00:03:53.520
as I closed these windows I'll leave them
open, we might need them in a minute.

78
00:03:53.520 --> 00:03:57.252
Flip back over here,
do a little ipconfig again.

79
00:03:57.252 --> 00:04:02.017
And now, I can see I've got
a different IP address, 10.0.100.11.

80
00:04:02.017 --> 00:04:06.596
DHCP is enabled,
I can see who my DHCP server is,

81
00:04:06.596 --> 00:04:10.410
I can see how long that lease is good for.

82
00:04:10.410 --> 00:04:13.394
So I'm getting this IP address, from DHCP.

83
00:04:13.394 --> 00:04:20.362
And if we flip over to the DHCP server,
we'll switch back to DC1 and I refresh.

84
00:04:20.362 --> 00:04:25.660
We should see, there it is, client 01,
is picking up that IP address from DHCP.

85
00:04:25.660 --> 00:04:27.760
Now the reason this is working, Ronnie,

86
00:04:27.760 --> 00:04:30.260
is if we look at the way
the network is structured.

87
00:04:30.260 --> 00:04:32.570
This is pretty much what we've got.

88
00:04:32.570 --> 00:04:34.710
We have our DHCP server.

89
00:04:36.160 --> 00:04:39.800
Which is by demand control,
or DC01 that's running DHCP.

90
00:04:39.800 --> 00:04:42.020
There's a switch,
that these nodes are connected to,

91
00:04:42.020 --> 00:04:45.200
and my client is connected to this switch.

92
00:04:45.200 --> 00:04:50.430
And so switches, they allow broadcast
traffic, they don't try to block anything.

93
00:04:50.430 --> 00:04:53.280
They're not making that contention domain.

94
00:04:53.280 --> 00:04:56.190
And so the client's hollering out,
I need an IP address,

95
00:04:56.190 --> 00:04:59.820
the server's hearing that,
responding with that offer.

96
00:04:59.820 --> 00:05:03.650
The client is then requesting, and
the server is acknowledging, and

97
00:05:03.650 --> 00:05:05.560
it can begin using the IP address.

98
00:05:05.560 --> 00:05:06.976
So everything's working great.

99
00:05:06.976 --> 00:05:10.624
But now let's imagine,
we've got another subnet over here.

100
00:05:10.624 --> 00:05:13.508
There's another switch and
I've got a router,

101
00:05:13.508 --> 00:05:15.840
sitting in between these two subnets.

102
00:05:15.840 --> 00:05:17.870
So we can route traffic, back and forth.

103
00:05:17.870 --> 00:05:23.230
And this is a Windows Server 2016 box,
that's running, routing and remote access.

104
00:05:23.230 --> 00:05:28.360
So, what would happen if,
we take this client and move it.

105
00:05:28.360 --> 00:05:33.080
We'll pretend, that we've got him
on the other subnet over here.

106
00:05:33.080 --> 00:05:37.210
>> So, let me kinda review and make sure,
I have this right in my head, Mike.

107
00:05:37.210 --> 00:05:39.880
So the reason why DHCP worked
effectively the first time,

108
00:05:39.880 --> 00:05:44.210
is because the DHCP server and
the client itself, are on the same subnet.

109
00:05:44.210 --> 00:05:45.560
But what you're now saying though,

110
00:05:45.560 --> 00:05:49.990
instead, is that DHCP client itself is
on some unknown subnet at this point.

111
00:05:49.990 --> 00:05:53.310
But my DHCP server's actually
on a different network.

112
00:05:53.310 --> 00:05:56.640
And what we've now done,
is put a router in between.

113
00:05:56.640 --> 00:06:00.000
So now that I have a router in between,
it's gonna block all broadcast.

114
00:06:00.000 --> 00:06:01.140
>> Exactly.

115
00:06:01.140 --> 00:06:02.240
>> All right Mike, how's this gonna work.

116
00:06:02.240 --> 00:06:03.642
>> Let's see what happens here.

117
00:06:03.642 --> 00:06:06.336
Let's go ahead and on our client.

118
00:06:09.437 --> 00:06:12.940
Let's see if what we're talking about,
rings true.

119
00:06:12.940 --> 00:06:14.860
So let's clear this up.

120
00:06:15.960 --> 00:06:21.480
And I'll do an ipconfig/release
to throw away,

121
00:06:21.480 --> 00:06:23.520
well if I elevate my prompt I'll do that.

122
00:06:23.520 --> 00:06:25.785
So let's get an administrative PowerShell.

123
00:06:27.598 --> 00:06:29.631
Yes to the good old UAC.

124
00:06:29.631 --> 00:06:35.380
And we'll do an ipconfig /release, to
throw away my current release information.

125
00:06:35.380 --> 00:06:36.780
No big deal.

126
00:06:36.780 --> 00:06:38.240
And let's move the client.

127
00:06:38.240 --> 00:06:39.930
I forgot to move him.

128
00:06:39.930 --> 00:06:41.380
Let's actually move him.

129
00:06:41.380 --> 00:06:44.900
I moved him in the drawing, but
not in the virtual realm here.

130
00:06:44.900 --> 00:06:47.510
So what I'm gonna do, is I'm simply
gonna do just like in my drawing,

131
00:06:47.510 --> 00:06:50.980
I happen to be doing it through the
Hyper-V settings for this Virtual Machine.

132
00:06:50.980 --> 00:06:53.890
Is I'm gonna change the network
that it's connected to.

133
00:06:53.890 --> 00:06:58.200
I'm gonna connect him to that
other subnet, internal two.

134
00:06:58.200 --> 00:07:01.210
I'm gonna click OK, to apply that change.

135
00:07:01.210 --> 00:07:07.248
So it'd be just like moving a cable in
your closet, from one switch to another.

136
00:07:07.248 --> 00:07:14.237
And let me do an ipconfig/renew and
see what happens.

137
00:07:14.237 --> 00:07:16.707
And we give it a minute,
but as Ronnie pointed out,

138
00:07:16.707 --> 00:07:19.960
we're pretty sure we know
what's gonna happen, right?

139
00:07:19.960 --> 00:07:21.260
>> Right.
At this point,

140
00:07:21.260 --> 00:07:25.000
when we start seeing this, what Mike
has issued here, of course, with that

141
00:07:25.000 --> 00:07:29.700
idea of the renew ,is that he's manually
forcing that door process to begin.

142
00:07:29.700 --> 00:07:31.610
So what should happen from this client,

143
00:07:31.610 --> 00:07:36.230
is that it should begin to broadcast out
its discover message and it's gonna hit

144
00:07:36.230 --> 00:07:39.950
every device on that network,
that's listening for this broadcast.

145
00:07:39.950 --> 00:07:41.580
And it's gonna hit that router interface.

146
00:07:41.580 --> 00:07:45.010
So Mike, you said that with that router
in place we can still do this, but

147
00:07:45.010 --> 00:07:46.090
it doesn't look like it's working.

148
00:07:46.090 --> 00:07:47.750
>> It doesn't, right?

149
00:07:47.750 --> 00:07:50.426
It is not giving me an IP address.

150
00:07:50.426 --> 00:07:55.259
It's eventually gonna time out and
we should know from Network+,

151
00:07:55.259 --> 00:07:59.091
we'll end up with an APIPA
address of 169254.

152
00:07:59.091 --> 00:08:00.204
Something, something.

153
00:08:00.204 --> 00:08:03.124
169.254.something.something.

154
00:08:03.124 --> 00:08:07.540
Because he's trying to get an IP address,
but he can't find the DHCP server.

155
00:08:07.540 --> 00:08:11.150
Nobody on his subnet is
providing that information.

156
00:08:11.150 --> 00:08:13.590
So then the question is,
how can we do this?

157
00:08:13.590 --> 00:08:18.090
We could set up a DHCP server
on every single subnet.

158
00:08:18.090 --> 00:08:19.940
I mean, that's a possibility, right?

159
00:08:19.940 --> 00:08:24.779
But that would mean extra servers and the
DHCP is not a big consumer of resources,

160
00:08:24.779 --> 00:08:27.626
so we're really gonna
end up wasting resources

161
00:08:27.626 --> 00:08:30.496
if we try to set up DHCP
servers on every subnet.

162
00:08:30.496 --> 00:08:33.698
Especially when we can
configure it to where one DHCP

163
00:08:33.698 --> 00:08:36.430
server can support multiple subnets.

164
00:08:36.430 --> 00:08:38.650
So let's see how we can do that.

165
00:08:38.650 --> 00:08:43.930
The first thing we're gonna do is
make sure that on our DHCP server,

166
00:08:43.930 --> 00:08:45.920
we have an appropriate scope.

167
00:08:45.920 --> 00:08:50.620
So here's the scope for that other subnet
that I just connected the client to.

168
00:08:50.620 --> 00:08:55.170
You can see it's a 192.168 address, so
we'll be able to tell the difference.

169
00:08:55.170 --> 00:08:57.690
And I've got a pool of
addresses available.

170
00:08:57.690 --> 00:08:59.126
All right, so everything is looking there.

171
00:08:59.126 --> 00:09:01.920
DHCP itself is set up.

172
00:09:01.920 --> 00:09:03.240
The server's waiting and he's saying, hey,

173
00:09:03.240 --> 00:09:07.040
if anybody needs an IP address
from this particular subnet,

174
00:09:07.040 --> 00:09:10.130
I've got a pool of addresses and
I'd be more than glad to give you one.

175
00:09:10.130 --> 00:09:14.940
The problem is that the client is never
able to reach the DHCP server to ask for

176
00:09:14.940 --> 00:09:15.670
that IP address.

177
00:09:15.670 --> 00:09:17.970
That's what's being blocked by the router.

178
00:09:17.970 --> 00:09:21.230
So we're gonna go over to our router.

179
00:09:22.420 --> 00:09:26.800
Server one and I've all ready done
this what we're gonna need to

180
00:09:26.800 --> 00:09:29.630
install routing and remote access, right?

181
00:09:29.630 --> 00:09:34.894
That's gonna give us the ability to
create what we call a DHCP relay agent,

182
00:09:34.894 --> 00:09:35.738
all right?

183
00:09:35.738 --> 00:09:40.103
And it's just like the name implies,
he's gonna relay information.

184
00:09:40.103 --> 00:09:45.040
You can imagine a subnet over here on
the right, a subnet over here on the left.

185
00:09:45.040 --> 00:09:48.250
And then this routing [INAUDIBLE]
access server sitting in the middle.

186
00:09:48.250 --> 00:09:50.630
And he's got connections to both sides,
right?

187
00:09:50.630 --> 00:09:55.230
So he's gonna hear that client over here
hollering out, I need an IP address.

188
00:09:55.230 --> 00:09:57.030
And nobody's every gonna answer him.

189
00:09:57.030 --> 00:09:59.490
But the router also has
a connection to the other side, and

190
00:09:59.490 --> 00:10:01.377
he knows where the DHCP server is.

191
00:10:01.377 --> 00:10:05.910
So all he's gonna do is just simply take
that information, that client's request,

192
00:10:05.910 --> 00:10:09.600
and since the client can't get
there he'll wrap it up and

193
00:10:09.600 --> 00:10:13.340
send it over to the DHCP server
on behalf of the client.

194
00:10:13.340 --> 00:10:17.530
He's relaying that request over
to the DHCP server, all right?

195
00:10:17.530 --> 00:10:22.636
And then the DHCP server is gonna respond

I've got machines that are named
server one, server two, server three,

500
00:25:43.029 --> 00:25:46.520
printer one, or printservo one,
Client123, what have you.

501
00:25:48.500 --> 00:25:54.400
What can happen is a non-windows
device can come into my network.

502
00:25:54.400 --> 00:25:57.210
And it can attempt to register a name

503
00:25:57.210 --> 00:26:00.320
that's already been registered
by another machine.

504
00:26:00.320 --> 00:26:03.270
Or maybe not register, but update.

505
00:26:03.270 --> 00:26:06.700
Let's say that I've got a machine
on my network called server one.

506
00:26:06.700 --> 00:26:09.780
Ronnie comes in with his laptop
that's running Linux and

507
00:26:09.780 --> 00:26:12.010
he comes into my network,
he's here to sell me with some things.

508
00:26:12.010 --> 00:26:13.306
I'm like, go away Ronnie.

509
00:26:13.306 --> 00:26:14.484
>> [LAUGH]
>> But no, I wouldn't do that,

510
00:26:14.484 --> 00:26:16.440
he's a nice guy, he can sell me whatever.

511
00:26:16.440 --> 00:26:20.480
But they come in and their machine
happens to be named servo one.

512
00:26:20.480 --> 00:26:24.460
And that machine does its normal thing
when he connects it to my network.

513
00:26:24.460 --> 00:26:28.410
It gets a DHCP address,
it sees the IP address of the DNS server.

514
00:26:28.410 --> 00:26:31.250
That network stack on Linux
calls up DHCP and says, hey,

515
00:26:31.250 --> 00:26:34.960
I need to create a record so
people can find me.

516
00:26:34.960 --> 00:26:37.720
There's already a record with my name,
great, I'll just update it.

517
00:26:37.720 --> 00:26:42.150
And now all of a sudden that record gets
updated with Ronnie's laptop's IP address.

518
00:26:42.150 --> 00:26:45.160
So when a user on my network is
trying to connect to server one,

519
00:26:45.160 --> 00:26:48.870
they end up getting the IP
address of Ronnie's machine.

520
00:26:48.870 --> 00:26:52.070
So you can definitely see
some problems with that.

521
00:26:52.070 --> 00:26:55.170
Could also be an intentional thing.

522
00:26:55.170 --> 00:26:58.330
I could do a denial of service
on you by trying to squat one of

523
00:26:58.330 --> 00:26:59.580
the names of your servers.

524
00:26:59.580 --> 00:27:03.564
All of a sudden none of your users can
connect to their mailboxes because I

525
00:27:03.564 --> 00:27:07.170
brought in a laptop that has the same
name as your mailbox server.

526
00:27:07.170 --> 00:27:10.630
And I try to update that IP address,
so you see where I'm going with that.

527
00:27:10.630 --> 00:27:15.488
So name protection creates
a new record in DNS,

528
00:27:15.488 --> 00:27:20.231
and along with DHCP,
that DHC ID, all right?

529
00:27:20.231 --> 00:27:24.948
And that record ties the identity
of the machine with that lease or

530
00:27:24.948 --> 00:27:29.480
that DHCP information,
that IP address registration.

531
00:27:29.480 --> 00:27:34.350
And so what happens is when
a client tries to contact DHCP and

532
00:27:34.350 --> 00:27:37.920
update that information,
renew that lease, what have you,

533
00:27:37.920 --> 00:27:42.660
it can check to see if that's the actual
machine that originally created it.

534
00:27:42.660 --> 00:27:43.764
Or let me rephrase that,

535
00:27:43.764 --> 00:27:46.666
cuz you're actually updating your
information on DNS not DHCP.

536
00:27:46.666 --> 00:27:48.570
So you go to contact DHCP.

537
00:27:48.570 --> 00:27:54.700
Again, Ronnie's laptop that happens to be
named server one, connects, talks to DHCP.

538
00:27:54.700 --> 00:27:57.975
Can't get my DNS, yeah,
got my acronyms going crazy here.

539
00:27:57.975 --> 00:28:01.800
>> [LAUGH]
>> Ronnie's laptop talks to DNS and says,

540
00:28:01.800 --> 00:28:05.240
hey, I need to update that information,
here's my IP address.

541
00:28:05.240 --> 00:28:07.383
DNS can contact DHCP and say,

542
00:28:07.383 --> 00:28:11.860
is this the client that originally
created this, all right?

543
00:28:11.860 --> 00:28:15.480
And if not, DNS can say no,
you're not allowed to update that record.

544
00:28:15.480 --> 00:28:16.630
That record is locked.

545
00:28:16.630 --> 00:28:20.380
Only the originator, the one that
originally created that record that got

546
00:28:20.380 --> 00:28:23.070
that lease,
is going to be able to update information.

547
00:28:23.070 --> 00:28:26.372
That is name protection and
it's a simple check mark.

548
00:28:26.372 --> 00:28:28.420
Let's take a look at my screen here.

549
00:28:28.420 --> 00:28:31.730
And we can go, you can actually do
this at a couple different places.

550
00:28:31.730 --> 00:28:35.938
Go to Properties, not on the server,
Michael, of IPv4.

551
00:28:35.938 --> 00:28:41.436
I can right-click on that, I can go to
Properties, and I can go to Advanced.

552
00:28:41.436 --> 00:28:43.310
And I thought that's where it was.

553
00:28:43.310 --> 00:28:44.352
I lied to you.

554
00:28:47.800 --> 00:28:48.465
>> And
protection there on the bottom, yep.

555
00:28:48.465 --> 00:28:49.860
>> There it is, I'm blind.

556
00:28:49.860 --> 00:28:50.610
Thank you, Ronnie.

557
00:28:50.610 --> 00:28:54.350
Name protection, DHP name protection
is disabled at the server level.

558
00:28:54.350 --> 00:28:58.720
I can choose Configure, and
I can enable name protection.

559
00:28:58.720 --> 00:29:02.525
We can do that IPv4,
we can also do it for IPv6.

560
00:29:02.525 --> 00:29:06.630
We can also do it for an individual scope.

561
00:29:06.630 --> 00:29:08.490
Actually, let's see if
I can find it in here.

562
00:29:08.490 --> 00:29:12.830
We go Properties > Advanced, and

563
00:29:12.830 --> 00:29:16.860
there it is right there on my DNS tab,
configured name protection.

564
00:29:16.860 --> 00:29:20.750
So maybe you only wanna provide name
protection on one particular scope,

565
00:29:20.750 --> 00:29:24.150
like your scope that supports all of
your servers or something like that.

566
00:29:24.150 --> 00:29:26.740
So you can enable it at the IPv4 level,

567
00:29:26.740 --> 00:29:31.186
at the IPv6 level, at the server level,
or at the individual scope level.

568
00:29:31.186 --> 00:29:33.875
>> Now Mike, I do have a question on that,
cuz it sounds like a neat thing.

569
00:29:33.875 --> 00:29:36.955
But what if I intentionally
am replacing a sever,

570
00:29:36.955 --> 00:29:40.195
such as my original server dies,
that server01.

571
00:29:40.195 --> 00:29:44.384
And I go, I need to bring server01 back up
and I'm gonna put new hardware on it and

572
00:29:44.384 --> 00:29:45.620
I now have server01.

573
00:29:45.620 --> 00:29:49.700
Do I need to uncheck this and
then we're fine or [CROSSTALK].

574
00:29:49.700 --> 00:29:52.201
>> With that,
you know that's a good question, Ronnie.

575
00:29:52.201 --> 00:29:55.775
And I believe you're gonna have manually
go in and just remove those records and

576
00:29:55.775 --> 00:29:56.801
update information.

577
00:29:56.801 --> 00:29:57.984
You definitely don't want to turn it off.

578
00:29:57.984 --> 00:30:01.227
>> [LAUGH]
>> And turn it back on cuz it'll end up

579
00:30:01.227 --> 00:30:05.970
generating these DHCP ID records and
you don't need multiples of those.

580
00:30:05.970 --> 00:30:09.450
So it'd be to just manually clear
that out, update that information,

581
00:30:09.450 --> 00:30:10.530
and you'll be good to go.

582
00:30:10.530 --> 00:30:12.700
Honestly, it's gonna be the DNS record.

583
00:30:12.700 --> 00:30:16.709
So if you remove the DNS record, that
new machine creates that new DNS record,

584
00:30:16.709 --> 00:30:18.000
you should be good to go.

585
00:30:18.000 --> 00:30:18.830
>> All right, Mike, well,

586
00:30:18.830 --> 00:30:24.190
that's a lot more on the idea of
maintaining of course and managing DHCP.

587
00:30:24.190 --> 00:30:27.480
But there's actually more for
us to also take a look at as well.

588
00:30:27.480 --> 00:30:31.070
So remember that when we took
a look at here in this episode

589
00:30:31.070 --> 00:30:35.230
is the idea of working with the leases and
showing how you can change the leases.

590
00:30:35.230 --> 00:30:38.200
As well as taking,
we got backup and restoration and

591
00:30:38.200 --> 00:30:41.640
even working with name protection to
prevent something like what would,

592
00:30:41.640 --> 00:30:44.950
DNS squatting, I think is technically
what we're actually talking about here.

593
00:30:44.950 --> 00:30:47.810
So to actually take a look
at those issues as well.

594
00:30:47.810 --> 00:30:49.090
But there is more to go.

595
00:30:49.090 --> 00:30:51.900
We need to talk about some failover,
we need to talk about a few other items.

596
00:30:51.900 --> 00:30:54.800
But that's gonna be for another part then.

597
00:30:54.800 --> 00:30:56.900
So it's a great place for us to sign off.

598
00:30:56.900 --> 00:30:59.970
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

599
00:30:59.970 --> 00:31:00.833
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

600
00:31:00.833 --> 00:31:05.915
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Networking with Windows Server 2016.

601
00:31:05.915 --> 00:31:12.008
[MUSIC]

602
00:31:12.008 --> 00:31:17.660
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike continue with managing and maintaining DHCP.  They describe setting up DHCP for HA and Failover, not simply running DHCP on a clustered server group.  Also they demonstrate how to configure and some of the options that must set to insure it’s implementation.  The team briefly mentions the places within DHCP to check the dhcp logs and in the event viewer when needing to troubleshoot dhcp operations.
episodes.title: Manage and Maintain DHCP Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:02.680
Welcome to IT Pro TV, I'm your host Don
>> [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:02.680 --> 00:00:07.842
>> [SOUND]

3
00:00:07.842 --> 00:00:09.112
>> [MUSIC]

4
00:00:09.112 --> 00:00:10.525
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

5
00:00:10.525 --> 00:00:14.772
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on IT Pro TV.

6
00:00:14.772 --> 00:00:16.484
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and

7
00:00:16.484 --> 00:00:20.700
today we're taking a look at
networking with Windows server 2016.

8
00:00:20.700 --> 00:00:23.220
We're specifically going into
a part two on managing and

9
00:00:23.220 --> 00:00:26.500
maintaining DHCP inside
of Microsoft Windows.

10
00:00:26.500 --> 00:00:29.900
And here to help us is our Microsoft kung
fu master himself, Mister Mike Rodrick.

11
00:00:29.900 --> 00:00:31.260
Mike, welcome back to our studio.

12
00:00:31.260 --> 00:00:33.860
>> Thanks for having me, Ronnie, and
thanks for allowing me to come in and

13
00:00:33.860 --> 00:00:36.040
teach you guys all about good old DHCP.

14
00:00:36.040 --> 00:00:39.840
Anyway, we're continuing on with DHCP,
in this one.

15
00:00:39.840 --> 00:00:44.760
We wanna take a look at how we can
provide some fault tolerance for DHCP.

16
00:00:44.760 --> 00:00:49.060
We've already talked a little bit
about disaster recovery backups,

17
00:00:49.060 --> 00:00:53.080
making sure we've got our automatic
backups setup the way we want it.

18
00:00:53.080 --> 00:00:56.170
That we are performing manual backups for

19
00:00:56.170 --> 00:00:59.340
offsite, other types of
disasters we might have.

20
00:00:59.340 --> 00:01:01.600
But now I wanna talk
about high availability.

21
00:01:01.600 --> 00:01:04.630
Just making sure that DHCP is available.

22
00:01:04.630 --> 00:01:05.745
And in the past,

23
00:01:05.745 --> 00:01:09.902
providing high availability on
DHCP was really no easy task.

24
00:01:09.902 --> 00:01:14.175
You could because DHCP
was very independent.

25
00:01:14.175 --> 00:01:17.193
It didn't share its information
with other DHCP servers.

26
00:01:17.193 --> 00:01:21.000
So when you were setting them up,
you had to do several things.

27
00:01:21.000 --> 00:01:24.050
You had to make sure that there
was no overlapping scopes.

28
00:01:24.050 --> 00:01:25.400
And it was good about warning you, but

29
00:01:25.400 --> 00:01:29.450
you couldn't have a scope overlap
because DHCP didn't talk to each other.

30
00:01:29.450 --> 00:01:32.640
So we had two servers that
had two different scopes but

31
00:01:32.640 --> 00:01:34.220
those scopes overlapped a little bit.

32
00:01:34.220 --> 00:01:37.170
If there were no safety checks,
you could have two servers passing

33
00:01:37.170 --> 00:01:41.290
out the same IP addresses,
causing duplicate IP addresses use, and

34
00:01:41.290 --> 00:01:43.130
there were connectivity issues for
those nodes.

35
00:01:44.680 --> 00:01:47.690
How do I provide high availability

36
00:01:47.690 --> 00:01:50.095
if I can't have two servers
that have the same scope.

37
00:01:50.095 --> 00:01:54.346
We would do things like
splitting up a scope and

38
00:01:54.346 --> 00:01:57.946
putting 80% of it on one server and
20 % on another.

39
00:01:57.946 --> 00:02:01.220
That way the 80% server would be
able to handle the workload but

40
00:02:01.220 --> 00:02:05.030
if it ever failed the other one
had 20% of the addresses and

41
00:02:05.030 --> 00:02:09.250
could kinda keep chugging along
if that first one had failed.

42
00:02:09.250 --> 00:02:15.010
>> Now Mike, I understand the idea of
backing up a server and getting it to

43
00:02:15.010 --> 00:02:20.080
that point where if that server actually
fails, I need to restore the DHTP.

44
00:02:20.080 --> 00:02:21.850
It means that I have to go ahead and

45
00:02:21.850 --> 00:02:26.390
reinstall DHTP,
get that backup database up and going.

46
00:02:26.390 --> 00:02:28.640
One makes high availability
special though.

47
00:02:28.640 --> 00:02:30.910
What are we really talking about here.

48
00:02:30.910 --> 00:02:32.815
When one server fails, what happens.

49
00:02:32.815 --> 00:02:36.250
>> We're talking about limiting
the downtime s really what it's about.

50
00:02:36.250 --> 00:02:40.070
When that server fails,
in Ronnie's scenario there for one,

51
00:02:40.070 --> 00:02:41.405
I get to discover that it's failed.

52
00:02:41.405 --> 00:02:44.380
And that's probably not gonna
be instantaneous because

53
00:02:44.380 --> 00:02:45.820
people have leases already.

54
00:02:45.820 --> 00:02:48.070
So it's gonna be when a new
client comes into the network and

55
00:02:48.070 --> 00:02:48.990
cannot obtain a lease.

56
00:02:48.990 --> 00:02:52.320
I'm gonna have to go figure out what's
wrong, find out that that server,

57
00:02:52.320 --> 00:02:54.130
that service is no longer running.

58
00:02:54.130 --> 00:02:55.530
And then I've gotta go get my backup.

59
00:02:55.530 --> 00:02:57.340
I've gotta do my restore.

60
00:02:57.340 --> 00:03:00.370
And in the meantime, I've got
clients waiting for IP addresses or

61
00:03:00.370 --> 00:03:02.740
trying to renew addresses and they can't.

62
00:03:02.740 --> 00:03:05.060
So we wanna try to prevent that downtime.

63
00:03:05.060 --> 00:03:06.950
That's where the high
availability comes in.

64
00:03:06.950 --> 00:03:08.710
And as I said, you really couldn't do it.

65
00:03:08.710 --> 00:03:13.680
One thing you would see people doing
was put DHCP on a failover cluster.

66
00:03:13.680 --> 00:03:16.720
But that's again a lot
of setup involved and

67
00:03:16.720 --> 00:03:19.630
hardware involved in
creating a failover cluster.

68
00:03:19.630 --> 00:03:22.220
And then putting DHCP on top of that.

69
00:03:22.220 --> 00:03:25.765
And then that way, you weren't really
doing anything to DHCP directly.

70
00:03:25.765 --> 00:03:28.250
Tt was underneath there
was some fault tolerance.

71
00:03:28.250 --> 00:03:29.780
So if that node failed,

72
00:03:29.780 --> 00:03:33.410
the roll would shift over to another node
using your fail over cluster method.

73
00:03:34.840 --> 00:03:37.600
Recently they've added, and
this was a couple additions ago so

74
00:03:37.600 --> 00:03:43.960
it's not brand new to 2016 by any means,
is we can do DHCP fail over.

75
00:03:43.960 --> 00:03:47.870
And that's a fail over
method within DHCP itself.

76
00:03:47.870 --> 00:03:52.120
We can now have our DHCP
servers working together.

77
00:03:52.120 --> 00:03:55.960
Talking to each other,
sharing their information about the scope,

78
00:03:55.960 --> 00:03:59.800
about the leases that we have for
that particular scope, and

79
00:03:59.800 --> 00:04:02.890
communicating with each other,
checking the status of their partner.

80
00:04:02.890 --> 00:04:06.640
And if the other one is down, knowing,
hey, it's time for me to take over.

81
00:04:06.640 --> 00:04:07.880
So that's the idea here.

82
00:04:07.880 --> 00:04:13.120
DHCP fail over is a fail over method I can
implement within DHCP with multiple DHCP

83
00:04:13.120 --> 00:04:20.040
servers to provide that up time, that
availability that I might need for DHCP.

84
00:04:20.040 --> 00:04:23.430
>> Now the idea of high availability
is something that we really want to

85
00:04:23.430 --> 00:04:27.370
understand, because most networks
are really gonna want something like this.

86
00:04:27.370 --> 00:04:30.840
Especially if that network needs to be
up 24 hours a day, seven days a week.

87
00:04:30.840 --> 00:04:34.990
It's something that's very important in
todays world, because a lot of us can't

88
00:04:34.990 --> 00:04:38.360
afford the downtime even though we might
say we're just replacing the server.

89
00:04:38.360 --> 00:04:42.600
It still takes time to bring up even a
virtual server and get the role installed,

90
00:04:42.600 --> 00:04:46.150
get everything back up and
verify then that everything is working.

91
00:04:46.150 --> 00:04:47.160
With high availability,

92
00:04:47.160 --> 00:04:51.640
what we're saying is that we're not gonna
have that issue as much as possible.

93
00:04:51.640 --> 00:04:53.890
And that way by the way
that it's actually setup,

94
00:04:53.890 --> 00:04:57.680
we're saying that it can actually handle
the failover and still continue to run.

95
00:04:57.680 --> 00:05:00.590
And so it's a great option for
us to consider,

96
00:05:00.590 --> 00:05:02.420
especially we have all
the resource that we need.

97
00:05:02.420 --> 00:05:06.910
>> It really is and we think like I've
been saying, DHCP if it fails, okay,

98
00:05:06.910 --> 00:05:10.750
everybody's kind of okay for a little
while We've gotta try and get it back up.

99
00:05:10.750 --> 00:05:14.550
But what about scenarios like
we've got a heavy remote access.

100
00:05:14.550 --> 00:05:17.510
A lot of people are remoting into
the network do work from home or

101
00:05:17.510 --> 00:05:18.700
traveling sales people.

102
00:05:18.700 --> 00:05:20.720
They need an IP address when they connect.

103
00:05:20.720 --> 00:05:24.030
If DHCP is down the VPN server
might not be able to get those.

104
00:05:24.030 --> 00:05:26.740
And then also they can't connect and
what that's gonna do.

105
00:05:26.740 --> 00:05:27.810
Phone calls to the helpdesk.

106
00:05:27.810 --> 00:05:28.960
Hey did you know I can't connect.

107
00:05:28.960 --> 00:05:29.920
I can't connect.

108
00:05:29.920 --> 00:05:32.240
What if I'm a service provider.

109
00:05:32.240 --> 00:05:35.230
Now we're multiplying the number of phone
calls the people that are experiencing

110
00:05:35.230 --> 00:05:39.790
down time, because DHCP was unavailable
and that could end up costing me money.

111
00:05:39.790 --> 00:05:44.570
I'm sure I've got contracts, I've got
policies in place with our, what are-

112
00:05:44.570 --> 00:05:45.140
>> SLA's.

113
00:05:45.140 --> 00:05:49.510
>> SLA's in place that say hey we're
going to provide this level of up time.

114
00:05:49.510 --> 00:05:51.480
I need to be able to provide that.

115
00:05:51.480 --> 00:05:55.110
Otherwise, I'm gonna face
probably fines or fees or

116
00:05:55.110 --> 00:05:58.010
a loss of customers, so not a good thing.

117
00:05:58.010 --> 00:05:59.480
So how do we do it.

118
00:05:59.480 --> 00:06:01.190
It's actually pretty straightforward.

119
00:06:01.190 --> 00:06:03.850
Let's talk about it and

00:10:38.210 --> 00:10:41.620

00:10:41.620 --> 00:10:45.840
whether we're behind a client is behind

207
00:10:45.840 --> 00:10:49.870
Obscured external ports,
next 16 bits, the NAT device has to

208
00:10:49.870 --> 00:10:54.170

209
00:10:54.170 --> 00:10:56.670

210
00:10:56.670 --> 00:10:58.940
And then obscured external IP address,

211
00:10:58.940 --> 00:11:03.400
the last 32 bits of the address block,
this is the NAT device's external IP

212
00:11:03.400 --> 00:11:06.090
that's obscured to prevent
NAT from translating that.

213
00:11:06.090 --> 00:11:10.172
So we're specifying certain things that
the NAT server needs to be aware of, but

00:11:10.172 --> 00:11:13.067

as part of its communication.

00:11:13.067 --> 00:11:17.193

the address structure so it understands,

00:11:17.193 --> 00:11:21.280
it being the Teredo client, understands

00:11:21.280 --> 00:11:25.910
And so the last 64 bits,
just highlighting it kinda here,

00:11:25.910 --> 00:11:30.260
broken up into three distinct blocks are

00:11:30.260 --> 00:11:38.020
The first 64 bits right here identify

00:11:38.020 --> 00:11:40.730

00:11:40.730 --> 00:11:42.790

00:13:21.120 --> 00:13:22.640

00:13:22.640 --> 00:13:25.599
What a modem does, translate analog

257
00:13:25.599 --> 00:13:26.570
back and forth.

00:13:26.570 --> 00:13:31.155

259
00:13:31.155 --> 00:13:34.013
explains them and
translates them back and forth so

260
00:13:34.013 --> 00:13:37.390
we go from an analog to
a digital signal and back again.

00:13:37.390 --> 00:13:39.630
That's what a modem did traditionally for
us.

262
00:13:39.630 --> 00:13:42.280
The PortProxy acts like
this in one respect.

00:13:42.280 --> 00:13:45.420

00:13:45.420 --> 00:13:49.970

00:13:49.970 --> 00:13:54.812

00:13:54.812 --> 00:13:57.350

00:13:57.350 --> 00:14:00.330

00:14:00.330 --> 00:14:04.100

00:14:04.100 --> 00:14:07.010

00:14:07.010 --> 00:14:10.630

00:14:10.630 --> 00:14:13.750

272
00:14:13.750 --> 00:14:15.880

00:14:15.880 --> 00:14:18.150

00:17:37.344 --> 00:17:40.290

347

348
00:17:52.500 --> 00:17:54.319
I think I mentioned these

350
00:17:56.025 --> 00:17:57.640
I think we were setting up the VPN.

351
00:17:57.640 --> 00:18:01.191
We actually took a look at it in

the demo.

I think I pointed out that

I showed them to you, but I believe that I

So we use Microsoft Point-to-Point

We use that for encryption and

PPP is used for authentication.

You wanna make sure you know
the underlying protocols that are used to

achieve these end results.

361

L2TP, we use certificates for

integrity data authentication.

363

00:18:31.943 --> 00:18:36.122
PPP, point-to-point, is used for

365
00:18:36.122 --> 00:18:38.720
and IKEv2 for
setting up an IKEv2 solution.

366
00:18:38.720 --> 00:18:42.082
We'll use AES, which is the Advanced
Encryption Standard algorithm.

367
00:18:42.082 --> 00:18:46.142
Got varying factors there,

372

We talked about the fact that we can

375
00:19:10.920 --> 00:19:13.640
I liked that a lot because that

376

377
00:19:17.557 --> 00:19:20.428

Pretty standard thought

380
00:19:27.730 --> 00:19:30.390

381

a site access and connectivity.

382
00:19:34.320 --> 00:19:38.120

383
00:19:38.120 --> 00:19:42.379

384
00:19:42.379 --> 00:19:46.265

because of the fact that we're just

385

maybe there isn't good infrastructure.

386
00:19:50.674 --> 00:19:53.945

391

393

394
00:20:16.520 --> 00:20:20.760
I've worked in some countries

395
00:20:20.760 --> 00:20:24.710
You've got the other main city and

396

397
00:20:29.560 --> 00:20:32.682

398

399
00:20:35.473 --> 00:20:38.424

400
00:20:38.424 --> 00:20:42.816
And so you have to use long distance
point-to-point communication mechanisms to

401
00:20:42.816 --> 00:20:43.450

402
00:20:43.450 --> 00:20:47.571
You can't just say, well, just jump on
that fiber line that somebody drilled and

403
00:20:47.571 --> 00:20:51.594
laid for us because there may not be fiber
running across the rainforest, right.

404
00:20:51.594 --> 00:20:54.939
You just may not have that or
out in the savannah or on the plain or

405
00:20:54.939 --> 00:20:55.835

406
00:20:55.835 --> 00:20:59.915
And so you're gonna have to use things

00:22:24.938 --> 00:22:28.560
So we talked about the fact that
those things are traditionally

this, the Tunneling Protocols and

00:22:33.490 --> 00:22:36.430

Firewall ports, and making sure you

00:22:40.284 --> 00:22:44.216

you to be aware of.

444
00:22:58.650 --> 00:23:01.230
Just wanna make sure you're
familiar with that, okay?

Not so much advanced, not so

00:01:14.010 --> 00:01:15.800

the things that go on with them.

32
00:01:15.800 --> 00:01:20.650
So we're gonna start by talking about

00:01:20.650 --> 00:01:25.270

When we think about bandwidth,

be able to create an opportunity for

37
00:01:32.845 --> 00:01:37.915
us to do what's called aggregating our

38
00:01:37.915 --> 00:01:43.825
And as a result of that have the sum of
those connections together for us to use.

39
00:01:43.825 --> 00:01:46.375
We are talking about something
known as NIC Teaming, and

40
00:01:46.375 --> 00:01:49.175
this is one of the really cool
features we've had for some time now.

41
00:01:49.175 --> 00:01:51.815
It's not brand new in
Server 16 by any means.

42
00:01:51.815 --> 00:01:55.690
We've had this with Hyper-V, and
Hyper-V networking capabilities for

43
00:01:55.690 --> 00:01:59.300

across the major vendor stacks.

44
00:01:59.300 --> 00:02:03.060
VMware provides NIC Teaming capabilities,
Citrix does, Microsoft does.

45
00:02:03.060 --> 00:02:04.530
You can do this on any platform.

46
00:02:04.530 --> 00:02:06.580
It's not unique to Microsoft by any means.

47
00:02:06.580 --> 00:02:10.490
But we can combine multiple adapters
together, get the benefit of essentially

48
00:02:10.490 --> 00:02:15.030
a multipathing scenario, so that if one
of the adapters were to fail in the team,

49
00:02:15.030 --> 00:02:18.150
we have alternate paths available
to continue sending and receiving.

50
00:02:18.150 --> 00:02:22.070
Very important from a BCDR
perspective with regards to that,

51
00:02:22.070 --> 00:02:24.250
Business Continuity Disaster Recovery.

52
00:02:24.250 --> 00:02:28.714
Very important from a highly available and
fault tolerance environment perspective in

53
00:02:28.714 --> 00:02:32.289
terms of managing our connectivity and
our continued availability.

54
00:02:32.289 --> 00:02:35.992
And we can also get the benefit of
aggregating up the bandwidth around those

55
00:02:35.992 --> 00:02:39.340
adapters so that we get the sum total
of all of that connectivity, so

56
00:02:39.340 --> 00:02:43.280
that we're able to not only communicate,
but communicate more effectively,

57
00:02:43.280 --> 00:02:47.720
more efficiently, and of course, with the
benefit of all of that extra bandwidth.

58
00:02:47.720 --> 00:02:50.050
So we can bond together and
create a NIC Team, or

59
00:02:50.050 --> 00:02:53.550
create a NIC Team out of grouping
network adapters together.

60
00:02:53.550 --> 00:02:57.553
Up to 32 of them could be used as
a single network interface in Server 16.

61
00:02:57.553 --> 00:03:00.826
That's a fairly large number if you
think about the fact that we would

62
00:03:00.826 --> 00:03:04.326
be able to provide redundancy, and
allow for enhanced communication and

63
00:03:04.326 --> 00:03:06.600
management across those interfaces.

64
00:03:06.600 --> 00:03:09.120
Now that sounds like a large number,
and it is.

65
00:03:09.120 --> 00:03:12.760
And you have to keep in mind that many
hosts will probably not provide 32

66
00:03:12.760 --> 00:03:15.780
physical network adapters
that you can team together.

67
00:03:15.780 --> 00:03:20.360
But you may have cabinet based solutions,
where you've got blades that are providing

68
00:03:20.360 --> 00:03:24.460
infrastructure hosting, and
you may have the ability to essentially

69
00:03:24.460 --> 00:03:28.090
aggregate up and use a large number of
adapters in those kind of environments.

70
00:03:28.090 --> 00:03:33.140
Years ago, when you were working
in private environments,

71
00:03:33.140 --> 00:03:35.900
you were doing this kind of stuff and
I see it a lot these days.

72
00:03:35.900 --> 00:03:39.130
But when you were doing this years ago you
probably didn't see hosts that would have

73
00:03:39.130 --> 00:03:41.830
anywhere that kind of number,
I would think, of adapters.

74
00:03:41.830 --> 00:03:43.123
I mean,
maybe two would certainly be normal

75
00:03:43.123 --> 00:03:43.691
>> Maybe four.

76
00:03:43.691 --> 00:03:44.547
>> Maybe four.

77
00:03:44.547 --> 00:03:45.090
>> Yeah.

78
00:03:45.090 --> 00:03:47.201
>> Maybe eight,
if it was a really high end host, but

79
00:03:47.201 --> 00:03:49.330
you probably didn't get
much further than that.

80
00:03:49.330 --> 00:03:54.180
That was a lot, and it was probably a
fairly complex solution if you have that.

81
00:03:54.180 --> 00:03:57.190
But we can see certainly
